	Mwy o gyflog efo gradd yn y Gymraeg
	Cwyno am Saesneg ar docynnau drama Eileen Beasley
	Comisiynydd: ?Angen sefydlu perthynas newydd gyda?r llywodraeth?


					

					

				

				
					Ychwanegu Sylw

						Nid yw Golwg360 yn gyfrifol am y sylwadau isod nac o angenrheidrwydd yn cytuno ? nhw.


						Gofynnwn yn garedig i ddarllenwyr wneud defnydd doeth o?r gwasanaeth sylwadau ? ni ddylid ymosod ar unigolion na chynnwys unrhyw sylwadau a all fod yn enllibus. Meddyliwch cyn teipio os gwelwch yn dda.


						Er mwyn cael trafodaeth dda, gofynnwn i chi ddefnyddio eich enw go iawn a pheidio ? chuddio y tu ?l i ffugenwau.


						Gofynwn yn garedig i bawb ddarllen canllawiau ?Cyfrannu i elfennau rhyngweithiol Golwg360? yn ofalus cyn gadael sylwadau ar y gwasanaeth.


						Nodi Camddefnydd
Os ydych chi?n credu bod y neges yma?n torri rheolau?r wefan, cliciwch ar y ddolen ?Nodi camddefnydd? sy?n ymddangos wrth ymyl pob sylwad. Os bydd dau berson yn anhapus, bydd y neges yn dod yn ?l at Golwg360 i?w ddilysu.

	    Register with GP in preparation for swine flu


 People in eastern and coastal Kent are being urged to make sure they are registered with a GP so they can get a swine flu vaccination if they are part of the priority groups.

This call comes after news that the expected growth in new cases of swine flu is proving to be slower than predicted.

?

The number of people contacting their GP with swine flu-like symptoms across eastern and coastal Kent last week has increased to 28.3 per 100,000 population compared to 16.5 per 100,000 the week before. In England the rate is 28.5 per 100,000. These rates are below seasonal activity.

?

The two vaccinations being used in the UK have now been licensed and GPs should start immunising within the next month. 

?

Only people who are registered with a GP will be offered immunisation which will be focused so that protection is offered to those who most need it. People with underlying health conditions, such as heart disease and diabetes, and pregnant women will be among a 14 million-strong nationwide priority group which will get the vaccine first along with health workers. 

?

By being able to start the vaccination programme before a sharp rise in new infections, NHS Eastern and Coastal Kent?s Deputy Director of Public Health Andrew Scott-Clark believes many lives could be saved. 

?

He said: "Progress of the second wave of pandemic flu is proving to be slower than predicted. We may have got a lucky break with the way the virus has behaved giving us the opportunity to get the vaccinations underway.? 

?

The best way people can continue to protect themselves is by following good hygiene ? catch coughs or sneezes in a tissue and bin tissues as soon as possible. Simply remember: Catch It, Bin It, Kill It.

?

He added: ?People should prepare themselves by stocking up on over-the-counter remedies and by identifying a flu friend ? someone who does not have swine flu ? who can pick up their antivirals and any other supplies for them should they become ill.?

?

Anyone suspecting they have swine flu can check their symptoms on the National Pandemic Flu Service website www.direct.gov.uk/pandemicflu or call 0800 1 513 100 or 0800 1 513 200. They should not visit their GP.

?

Once people are confirmed with swine flu by the National Pandemic Flu Service, they will be given a unique authorisation number that the ?flu friend? can use to pick up the antivirals from a local antiviral collection point. 

?

Callers to the service will be told where their nearest antiviral collection point is. 

However, people with swine flu symptoms should only contact their doctor direct rather than using the National Pandemic Flu Service if they:

?

	Have a serious underlying illness 
	Are pregnant 
	Have a sick child under one year old 
	Realise their condition is suddenly getting much worse 
	Think their condition is still getting worse after seven days (five for a child). 


???? 



12 October

	Dogs - Awareness and Enforcement

	As part of the Snodland Goes Cleaner campaign, Tonbridge & Malling Borough Council, with permission from Snodland Town Council held a Dogs Awareness and Enforcement event in Nevil Park and the Recreation Ground on 13 November 2008. Environmental Enforcement Officer bagged all the dog waste found in the two parks in bright yellow bags. The bags were left on the ground where they were found for the day to create a visual impact for the amount of dog waste in the two parks, before they were disposed of safely in the dog bins provided.



The officers also picked up all the litter in the two parks as a Bash the Trash event.

title: Paper D NHS SHEFFIELD  Board Meeting Transforming Community Services
text:
Paper D NHS SHEFFIELD  Board Meeting Transforming Community Services 
 
Transforming Community Services 
 
Board Meeting 
D D 
 
1 February 2011 
 
Author(s)/Presenter Jill Dentith, Head of Corporate Services  
and title Julia Newton, Director of Finance 
Sponsor Director Ian Atkinson, Interim Chief Executive 
Purpose of Paper 
 
Achieving the service transformation from Transforming Community Services (TCS) is a 
critical element of delivering the strategic change which will be outlined in Achieving 
Balanced Health (4).  A key step is to achieve the actual transfer of services from the PCT 
to the new providers on 1 April 2011. The purpose of this paper is to update Board 
members on progress and highlight certain issues which are emerging as detailed 
discussions now take place. The paper also gives assurances to the board, not only on 
the transactional process, but also the transformational vision that Partnership Boards 
have committed to. The paper also asks the Board to sign off the final proposal for 
Transformation of Community Services in Sheffield, subject to the Foundation Trust 
Boards' approval.

NHS Sheffield is the Sheffield Primary Care Trust  
 
Transforming Community Services 
 
 
Board Meeting 
 
1 February 2011 
1 Introduction 
 
Achieving the service transformation from Transforming Community Services (TCS) 
is a critical element of delivering the strategic change which will be outlined in 
Achieving Balanced Health (4).  A key step is to achieve the actual transfer of 
services from the PCT to the new providers on 1 April 2011. The purpose of this 
paper is to update Board members on progress and highlight certain issues which 
are emerging as detailed discussions now take place. The paper also gives 
assurances to the board, not only on the transactional process, but also the 
transformational vision that Partnership Boards have committed to. The paper also 
asks the Board to sign off the final proposal for Transformation of Community 
Services in Sheffield subject to the Foundation Trust Boards approval. 
 
2 Heads of Agreement 
 
Heads of Agreement for all three foundation trusts have been agreed and signed by 
all parties.  
 
Detailed work has taken place on Schedule 4 in each of the Heads of Agreement. 
Schedule 4 covers the key issues for resolution. For each issue a lead officer from 
NHS Sheffield is working with the relevant foundation trust lead to find a way 
forward as part of the contractual process or the business transfer agreement.  The 
list of outstanding issues for resolution is slightly different for each trust, but 
essentially covers areas such as staff, capital and other assets, matters arising 
from financial, clinical and legal due diligence work and arising from the 
Commissioning Intentions document previously approved by NHS Sheffield?s 
Board. 
 
3 Business Transfer Agreements 
 
The Business Transfer Agreement provides the documentation in relation to 
transfer of a range of assets, staff and contracts. This is a legally binding 
document.  A copy of the initial draft Transfer Agreement was shared with Board 
members in November 2010. An updated version will be presented to Board this 
month in private as this could be considered commercial in confidence.  
 
Now the Heads of Agreement are signed, the Transfer Agreement will be populated 
and shared with partners to agree a final version.  This document should be agreed 
prior to 1 April 2011.  The Board will be asked to give delegated powers to the 
Interim Chief Executive or Director of Finance to change and sign on behalf of NHS 
Sheffield. 
 
 
 
 
3
 
NHS Sheffield is the Sheffield Primary Care Trust 4  Feedback from Co-operation and Competition Panel (CCP) 
   
At the last meeting of the Board we confirmed that we had been advised by the 
CCP that in agreement with the Department of Health and Monitor they will not 
provide formal advice and recommendations on some mergers. This will be the 
case for the Sheffield proposal, excluding Primary Care Trust Medical Services. 
This was conditional upon the CCP being provided with statements on choice. We 
are in the process of submitting the relevant assurances from the Foundation 
Trusts and NHS Sheffield to CCP.   
 
5 Primary Care Trust Medical Services (PCTMS) 
 
It is proposed that Primary Care Trust Medical Services (PCTMS) be transferred to 
Sheffield Health and Social Care Trust. CCP have advised that the proposal around 
PCTMS will remain subject to CCP review.  A separate submission has been made 
to CCP regarding these services which included a signed Heads of Agreement.  
 
CCP have advised that they will select a case involving the transfer of GPs out of a 
PCT provider arm to consider the potential issues in the context of the Principles 
and Rules for Cooperation and Competition. CCP anticipate that case will take until 
early March to complete and they intend to use information from the Sheffield 
submission, and other similar cases, when reaching their view to consider as many 
variations of the issues as possible. At stages of the case CCP are likely to ask 
questions to confirm their understanding of our arrangements. By taking this 
approach CCP anticipate applying a fast-track type review to the remaining seven 
or eight cases, including the Sheffield submission. If CCP can complete the first 
case earlier they will be in a position to provide a view on the Sheffield case earlier. 
This still present us with a potential timing issue for the transfer which Board need 
to be aware of. 
 
It is proposed that staff will be consulted as part of the TUPE process in February, 
with other Provider Services staff, and that the transfer will be actioned on              
1 April 2011. However, the transfer will be subject to CCP approval.  
 
We are currently working on an Alternative Provider of Medical Services (APMS) 
contract for these services. The contract will include key performance indicators 
which we anticipate will be broadly the same as the new Personal Medical Services 
(PMS) contract. This will ensure that the practices in these services will be in line 
with other practices in the city. 
 
There is a substantial amount of work to do between now and the transfer date in 
relation to this service and timescales will need to be closely monitored. Board will 
be kept updated on progress.  
 
6 Shadow Partnership Boards 
 
The shadow Partnership Boards for both adult and children?s services have been 
established. These Boards will lead and drive the system changes in the provision 
of community services. To enable the boards to function effectively a review of the 
longer term governance arrangements for the Partnership Boards has been 
commissioned. Finnamores have led this work and have suggested a range of 
options which board members are considering.  
4
 
NHS Sheffield is the Sheffield Primary Care Trust  
 Following the January 2011 NHS Sheffield Board concerns were expressed that 
the short term requirement of making transition happen will delay and potentially 
undermine the prospects for real transformation.  It was agreed that assurances 
would be sought from the Shadow Partnership Boards in this respect. In response 
to these concerns the Children?s Shadow Partnership Board and Sheffield 
Teaching Hospital Foundation Trust (STHFT) on behalf of the shadow Adult 
Partnership Board have submitted information on how they want to assure NHS 
Sheffield Board of their intention to use the opportunities and vision for the 
transformation of service. These are attached at Appendix 1 and 2. The submission 
from Children?s has been developed jointly by Partnership Board members. The 
submission regarding adult services is based on that originally produced by the 
Adult Partnership Board but due to timing of our board papers has been updated by 
colleagues at STHFT. It is anticipated that this vision will be further refined in 
consultation to Partnership Board colleagues. Both Partnership Boards recognise 
the significant transactional agenda which is necessary to ensure safe services and 
business continuity from 1 April whilst setting out a clear vision for the longer term 
transformational change across acute and community services.  
 
7 Project Plan 
 
As reported at the last Board, the overall status for the project has now been rated 
as red by both the Shadow Partnership Boards. The main reasons for this status 
are that there are significant concerns in relation to resolution of the issues listed in 
Schedule 4 of the Heads of Agreement. These relate to funding levels, staffing and 
capital assets. This could have a knock on effect in relation to papers being taken 
to the respective foundation trust boards for approval. This milestone is also RAG 
rated red at this time. 
 
Despite the concerns noted above, it remains possible to achieve the April deadline 
and considerable work is ongoing. The TUPE transfer of most provider services 
staff is expected to be straight forward. In the last two weeks substantial progress 
has been made in relation to the staff transfer issues for support staff where there 
is no clear TUPE transfer to an individual foundation trust. A joint meeting between 
HR leads and Directors of Finance on 21 January 2011 was able to move this 
process forward significantly and we remain on track to allow staff affected by the 
transfer to receive letters at the beginning of February.  
 
Substantial progress has also been made in the last week in terms of the financial 
risk issues and contract negotiations, with NHS Sheffield making updated offers to 
each of the Foundation Trusts. At the time of writing this report, each of the 
Foundation Trusts are considering these proposals and undertaking further risk 
assessment work particularly with regard to the proposed cost improvement plans 
needed to support delivery of the 4% tariff efficiency requirement in 2011/12 and a 
sustainable financial position. A verbal update can be provided at the Board. 
 
Nationally the Department of Health continues to indicate that PCT?s may not 
transfer capital assets in the sense of buildings/estate as part of TCS arrangements 
and hence we are locally working through the arrangements which will be needed 
to sub let or offer licences for occupation by the three FTs and also the associated 
facilities management arrangements. NHS Sheffield has put forward a proposal 
which the three trusts are now considering. The Department of Health has also not 
5
 
NHS Sheffield is the Sheffield Primary Care Trust formally confirmed the position in relation to the transfer of other assets such as IT 
equipment but we are locally working on a solution which assumes that such 
transfers will be allowed. 
 
8 Formal agreement of the Transformation of Community Services 
 
At Board meetings in 2010 members were presented with the eight national and 
our local tests against which to assess proposals around transforming community 
services. The proposals for the transformation, as described in previous papers, fit 
with these tests. As described in Appendix 1 and 2 attached, the partnership 
boards will improve outcomes and quality, service integration, efficiencies, 
infrastructure utilisation, sustainability and whole system fit. These were all key 
principles which underpin the proposals and fit with the national and local tests.  
This work has been completed with comprehensive stakeholder engagement.  
 
Noting the above, NHS Sheffield Board is asked to agree that the services currently 
provided by Sheffield PCT Provider Services be transferred to Sheffield Teaching 
Hospitals NHS Foundation Trust, Sheffield Children?s NHS Foundation Trust and 
Sheffield Health and Social Care NHS Foundation Trust as detailed in Appendix 3 
This agreement is subject to the respective foundation trust getting approval from 
their respective Board or Investment Committee for the transfer.

SHEFFIELD CHILDREN?S SHADOW PARTNERSHIP BOARD  
 
TRANSFORMED COMMUNITY HEALTH SERVICES FOR CHILDREN IN SHEFFIELD  
 
DISCUSSION PAPER 
 
 
Members of the Sheffield Children?s Shadow Partnership Board are committed to 
improving the health outcomes for children living in the city. Members have agreed that 
the opportunities brought about by Transferring Community Services will be used to drive 
measurable improvement in the health of the younger age population, and that all partner 
organisations will commit to collaborating to achieve real change. This paper sets out the 
main aims of the strategy we are setting out to achieve, along with details of some of the 
tangible improvements we will aspire to deliver. 
 
1. VISION ? WHAT ARE WE SEEKING TO ACHIEVE? 
 
The overarching strategy for community health services for children should focus on 
prevention, early intervention and local delivery of care, provided within effective and 
integrated models of service delivery. Specifically, the main goals would be as follows: 
 
? To keep Sheffield?s children healthy, to help them achieve their potential, and live 
their lives to the full. 
 
? To make measurable improvement  to the health of the children living in the city 
 
? To provide integrated, joined up and seamless services that are easy to navigate 
for children, young people, carers and professionals.  
 
? To provide a service that joins together to meet the needs of the child when they 
need it, in a place as close to home as possible, that works in partnership to ensure 
smooth transition, avoid duplication and ensures that every child has the 
opportunity to live life to the full.  
 
? To provide a service that aims to keep children out of hospital and other ?high tier? 
care by addressing their needs as soon as possible, as locally as possible, 
focussing on prevention and public health. 
 
? To provide a service that is affordable, demonstrates value for money, is 
sustainable and flexible to respond to changing local needs. 
 
? To provide services for children which are staffed by a workforce who are confident 
and empowered to enable them to work flexibly and share roles to the benefit of the 
children in their care,  but with clarity in roles and responsibilities. 
 
? To ensure a high level of focus is given to  meeting the  needs of younger children 
and their families, to support effective child development and preventative 
approaches 
 
 
8
  
2. PRINCIPLES ? ?THE SHEFFIELD WAY? 
 
A number of key principles should underpin our joint approach: 
 
? We are committed to build relationships formed on trust and understanding and 
with the focus on outcomes for the child.  
 
? We understand and recognise the distinct value of locally-based community 
services, and the importance and value of managing and leading these services 
from within the community. 
 
? We recognise that families and children interact with a range of services and that 
organisational boundaries should not impede support or delay intervention. 
 
? We recognise that good health is not just about health services and requires a 
holistic approach   which seeks to understand and meet the needs of families. 
 
? We are committed to using evidence based approaches in order to maximise the 
effectiveness of community based services for children, with a particular emphasis 
on early year?s provision and services for children with long-term conditions. 
 
3.   DRAFT PROPOSALS FOR HEALTH OUTCOMES MEASURES FOR CHILDREN

to delivering a number of challenging or stretch targets. In setting out to work on a

families, there was agreement that the partnership would identify the outcomes by which it 
would judge its success.  Whilst these measures are still under development, it is 
anticipated that the performance framework would include the following:

 3.  OPPORTUNITIES 
 
The proposal to form a Partnership Board for Children offers the opportunity to take 
forward key service improvements and developments to services for children in a 
cohesive way. Through a partnership approach a number of significant improvement 
for children?s services are possible over the next three years (April 2011 to March 
2014). Key themes and priorities are given below: 
 
? Providing joined up services for  disabled children with complex needs with  a key 
worker to co-ordinate care and services provided where possible in one-stop shops 
? Ensuring that good communication exists between staff with effective co-working 
and with a reduction in duplication and effective use of resources. 
? Strengthen child and carer voice in all services. 
? Complete implementation of health visiting specification. 
? Information sharing strategy to become intrinsic to proactive. 
? Developing a clear model of universal provision starting from pre-birth and 
encompassing positive parenting. 
?  Improved access to dental care 
? Community services accessible to families in community centre and schools. 
? Preventative models at all stages including consistent health promotion. 
? Improved communication and links between all agencies ? health, social care and 
education. 
? Integrated training and development for the children?s workforce. 
? Reduced hospital admission. 
? Better early intervention ? faster connections and right service with less duplication. 
 
4. DRIVERS FOR CHANGE IN 2011 
 
Over recent years there have been many changes to the provision of community services 
for children, including the development of integrated practice and management. Primarily 
this has involved staff and services provided by Sheffield City Council and those provided 
by the Sheffield PCT.  Good progress has been made however it is now timely that 
partners now work together to determine a new vision for the future and ensure that 
resources are used with maximum effectiveness to meet the needs of children in 
Sheffield.  The specific drivers for change at this time are as follows: 
 
? NHS Sheffield?s withdrawal from direct provision of community health services for 
children in response to the nationally driven Transforming Community Services 
agenda. 
? Shared priority across commissioners and providers to reduce hospital admissions 
? Reduced funding in all areas  
? Shared priority to improve health services for children in their early years 
? New commissioning priorities and service specifications (Achieving Balanced Health 4) 
10
 ? The new White Paper ?Equity and Excellence: Liberating the NHS? emphasises the 
importance of developing personalised, effective services with an emphasis on 
preventative approaches.

Opportunities to transforming healthcare provision in Sheffield. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
January 2011 
 
14
  
1 Integrated Healthcare Vision and Strategy 
The ambition for adult services is to transform the way patients and citizens access 
local healthcare, with both a greater volume and breadth of tailored, personalised 
services being made available in peoples own homes or local communities, where 
safe and economical to do so. This will result in fewer services being provided 
through a hospital location, which in time will result in reduced hospital 
infrastructure with resources being transferred into community settings,.   
 
In order to deliver patient benefits and a sustainable and affordable healthcare 
system in Sheffield, the transformation process will not only include Provider Arm 
clinical services transferring to STH but also services currently provided by STH. 
 
STH plan to deliver this ambition by successfully and safely transferring services 
from the Provider arm to STH by 31 March 2011, and this is taking the majority of 
time and resource at the moment. For the first six months following transfer, the 
process of reviewing service transformation options and putting in place an 
implementation plan will take place. During this time projects that have already 
commenced will be continued and completed, and where agreed, newly emerging 
plans will start to be implemented. The main transformational programme will start 
once the transfer has been successfully completed and in any event no later than 
01 September 2011.  
 
Vision 
To meet the health and social care needs of citizens more effectively through an 
integrated health and social care service in Sheffield.     
 
We will achieve this by;  
1.1 Working with partners to develop an integrated health and social care 
strategy for the City. 
1.2 Developing local standards that patients and citizens can expect from the 
newly integrated health and social care services.   
1.3 Addressing service inequalities across the city.  
1.4 Personalising service packages that focus on preventing illness or the 
deterioration of health, including promoting the role of self-care and self-
management. 
1.5 Providing alternative options to hospital care, helping to avoid current 
inappropriate yet necessary hospital admission. 
1.6 Improving the patient and citizen experience. 
1.7 Delivering better value for money.  
1.8 Need to add in something explicitly about safety, effectiveness, quality... 
 
2 Benefits 
Both clinical and non-clinical savings and efficiencies will result in better patient 
care and economic savings. These will be quantified where possible during the 
transfer and transitional periods, but at this stage in the process it is difficult to 
quantify these benefits.   
 
2.1 Benefits for Patients 
A recent Interqual audit concluded that patients were admitted more 
frequently to hospital and stayed longer after the completion of their acute 
episode due, amongst other things, to insufficient or absent community 
15
 based alternatives to hospital. In some cases community based services are 
duplicated by the acute services ?out-reaching? into the community and 
community based service teams, and evidence indicated that delays exist for 
patients where they have to cross from one service provider to another. The 
transformational programme offers real opportunities to focus on delivering 
patient benefits by; 
2.1.1 supporting them on their journey through the health and social care 
system 
2.1.2 reducing the time taken waiting for the next stage of treatment 
2.1.3 standardising on evidence based pathways of care to deliver 
consistently better outcomes 
2.1.4 increasing patient and carer engagement in shaping personalised 
care packages 
2.1.5 avoiding unnecessary admission to hospital 
2.1.6 minimising length of hospital stay 
2.1.7 improve the safety and quality of services overall 
2.1.8 reducing the burden that duplication puts on patients and their 
families 
2.1.9 providing balanced, equally accessible community and home based 
services across the City  
2.1.10 improving the patient and carer experience  
2.1.11 improving the cost effectiveness of services and the value for money 
they offer. 
 
2.2 Clinical Transformation 
 
Integrating services will help to ensure a holistic approach to patient care. By 
bringing together the resources of primary care, acute services, relevant 
mental health services, Social care and community health services, the 
focus can be on meeting  local needs in the most co-ordinated and efficient 
manner to ensure best outcomes, maximising support whilst eliminating 
duplication and streamlining the transition between services to improve the 
patient experience.   In the medium term, this could mean integrating the 
community teams for older people with the Community Care Teams and 
where possible moving to ensure professional co-location.  
Care pathway redesign should facilitate personalised care and choice and 
the integration of care pathways is also likely to result in the following 
benefits; 
? Fewer handoffs between organisations with more streamlined 
pathways; 
? Potential for the creation of Single Points of Access and assessment 
for patients with social care and community services needs; 
? Fewer hospital admissions through the delivery of integrated 
healthcare with community support; 
? Reduction on length of stay through the integration of social care and 
community services allowing patients to be cared for outside the 
acute hospital setting. This could be enabled by an integrated 
discharge planning system which would target those specialties with 
long or higher than average LOS and those that interface with 
community care; 
? Avoidance of emergency readmissions, linked into the LOS initiative 
above; 
16
 ? Reduction in delayed transfers of care 
? Integration of health records. 
? The delivery of a better, integrated pathway would also allow for 
better management and control of intermediate healthcare which will 
assist the Trust in the management of the number of beds at the Trust 
and length of stay potentially leading to the closure of wards or the 
diversion of resources to other essential areas.  
 
Resultant savings  are likely to be in the following areas: 
? Reduction in length of stay; 
? Reduction in delayed transfers of care; 
? Reduction in readmissions; 
? Reduction in GP referrals to acute trust with greater use of community 
teams and facilities; 
? Reduction in A&E attendances; 
? Reduction in duplication of work; 
? Reduction in patient transfers; and 
? Improvement in numbers of District Nurse contacts per day. 
 
2.3 Rationalisation of management structures and governance 
Currently, services are delivered by two separate organisations with two 
separate boards and governance structures. The integration of services 
would allow the rationalisation of management and governance 
arrangements. The aim will be to create a more integrated management 
structure with efficiencies being achieved in management costs.  
 
2.4 Estates rationalisation 
Although property will not transfer to STH, there may be opportunities to 
release savings in the property portfolio through improved utilisation of 
estate with the consequent release of leased property.  
 
2.5 Back Office shared services 
Through the integration of the two organisations it should be possible to 
create a shared back office function providing IT, HR and Finance and other 
corporate/support services, such as procurement.  
 
2.6 Procurement Savings 
It is likely that by integration of the procurement processes greater scale 
efficiencies can be achieved.  
 
2.7 Human Resources 
 
The removal of organisational boundaries positively impacts on: 
? The establishment of clear and more effective communication lines; 
? Single entry point for services and personalised case management of 
high risk patients improves patient outcomes, their experience and 
staff morale. 
17
 ? The inclusion of the ?right? people with the ?right? skills thus delivering 
a joined up service across both the community and acute settings to 
provide an integrated service; 
? Joint education, training and development allows staff to work 
together sharing knowledge and experience; and 
? Users ? both internal and external ? have access to an enhanced 
shared knowledge base. 
 
3 Current transformation projects  
 
A number of transformational projects are underway that are planning to transform 
services and deliver patient benefits; 
 
3.1 Diabetes 
Services are being transformed so that more patients with type two diabetes 
have better access to community and primary care diabetes services, led 
and fully supported by STH senior consultants. 
 
3.2 Heart Failure 
The adult provider partnership board is supporting a short term review of the 
heart failure service aimed at integrating the two service provision teams and 
changing the focus of the service to be community facing. 
 
3.3 Hospital Admission avoidance 
Projects are underway with secondary, community and primary care 
involvement to establish a GP assessment unit and improve the 
management of people with dementia. The purpose of these two projects is 
to provide alternatives to accident and emergency and so reduce the 
number of people attending the department. 
 
3.4 Hospital Discharge 
This comprises a number of projects with community, social services and 
primary care involvement to speed up the discharge process. The projects 
currently underway are; 
? Home of choice 
? Improved discharge planning processes 
? Improved access to intermediate care 
 
This group of projects aim to reduce the demand for non-elective beds by 
improving community services that integrate with hospital based services. 
The result will be a reduction in the number of hospital beds and 
reinvestment in community services. 
 
In essence the proposals all consolidate into an integrated plan for winter 
and beyond aims to put new systems and process in place to reduce the 
number of people being admitted to hospital and rapidly discharges them 
back to their own homes or communities after the acute episode.  
 
4 Governance 
The adult provider partnership board APPB, will be the group that works with 
commissioners to interpret commissioning intentions and produce practical 
solutions to deliver the desired commissioning outputs. The APPB will establish 
18
 cross cutting project groups to tackle the barriers to achieving integrated care and 
developing integrated care pathways and act as the delivery board, ensuring that 
plans are being implemented according to timetable and delivering the anticipated 
benefits. 
 
5 Conclusions 
STH is committed to transforming healthcare in Sheffield, not just community 
services transferring from the Provider Arm. The Chief Executive has set out his 
vision for the transformation in several public meetings and the Board at STH 
support the need to transform the way services are provided to achieve stable and 
affordable services. However, the safe transfer of services by 31 March and a 
smooth transition period prior to the transformational programme is also needed. 
Evidence from pilots indicates that the most successful transformations occur 
where patients and service providers design and implement new pathways. STH is 
fully committed to these principles. 
19

title: Skin Cancer Hub - Know Your Skin
text:
Skin Cancer Hub - Know Your Skin
		



	



Advanced search
(Options)

��





	Hub Home
	About the Hub
	Contact Us
	Help
	Feedback
	News
	Events
	Latest Resources








	
		
			Intervention: Know Your Skin

			


General Information


Aims: Pharmacy staff to raise awareness of skin cancer prevention and spotting the signs early, and trigger appropriate presentation at GP, using skills learned at training, and 'Know Your Skin' quiz to prompt conversations.




Is this intervention part of a national initiative?: No





Source of funding: NHS




Lead Organisation: NHS Devon




Contact Name: Sarah Bird




Contact EMail: sarahbird1@nhs.net




Contact telephone: 01392 267754




Website: 




Partner organisation(s): Devon Local Pharmaceutical Committee, Torbay Care Trust





Intervention Detail


Start date: 30/05/2011




End date: 25/06/2011




Ongoing?: False


Target Population: Over 50s




Setting: Health, Community




Target region: South West




Target area: Devon









Intervention Focus


Main category: Prevention/Raising Awareness, Early Diagnosis




Sub Category: Information Giving/Awareness, Health Promotion, Social Marketing



Intervention evaluation


Status: Completed




Outcomes measured: Changes in behaviour, Changes in attitudes, Changes in knowledge




Results: Training had a significant impact on staff, increasing their confidence and knowledge in talking about skin cancer prevention and early diagnosis.

During the campaign, 897 conversations with customers were recorded. 405 quizzes returned by customers, and the median age of respondents was 52.

67% (261) of all respondents said that the quiz had raised their
awareness of skin cancer by 6 or above on a scale of 1 to 10. 

21% of over 50s said that the quiz had raised concerns about a
change that they had noticed in their skin. 88% of these said that they were going to book an appointment with their GP to get it checked out.

81% of over 50s said that they would feel comfortable discussing
the signs of skin cancer with a pharmacy member of staff.

38% of over 50s had had a conversation about skin cancer with a pharmacy member of staff that day.




Approximate costs: ����3500 (does not include staff time)




Lessons learnt/tips/advice: Resources: order resources very early on �� preferably four months, to allow for delays in supply.

Redesign quiz with tear-off slip so that customers can take home.

Staff find it easier to start conversations about skin cancer when the weather is sunny.

Allow plenty of time for collation and analysis if you are doing evaluation yourselves.





Uploaded resources:
Appendix 1 - Preventing Skin Cancer and Spotting Signs Early Training session handout
Appendix 2 - Know Your Skin Quiz
Appendix 3 - Know Your Skin Evaluation Forms
Appendix 4 - Know Your Skin results tables
Know Your Skin Report

					Sharing services

											
							Posted on October 18, 2011 by suemace | Leave a comment
													

					
					
						A successful bid by WHELF to CyMAL: Museums Archives Libraries Wales has funded a feasibility study into shared library management systems. This is seen as a potential area to drive further collaboration and forms a key part of the WHELF Action Plan 2011-13. Our strategic vision for the â??Sharing Library Services Programmeâ?? is toÂ enable access to the collective resources and services of a virtual academic library for Wales.

Our ambition is that the Programme will have direct impacts on individual learners and/or citizens, learning institutions and Wales as a vibrant knowledge economy;

	Individuals will be able to exploit the shared services delivered directly to them,
	learning institutions (across the sectoral boundaries) will find it easier to collaborate for learning, teaching and research and
	Wales will have a visible platform for access to knowledge within & to Welsh businesses as well as showcasing the knowledge created in Wales to economic and political partners.

text:
Sciencebase Science News and Views





	home
	book
	archives
	about
	
	



















Feb 25, 2013 

Sciencebase Twitter archive

			Posted at 3:45 pm by David Bradley 
			?
Now, that almost anyone can download an archive of all their twitter activity, there are a few neat things you can do with the data once you?ve got it. For instance, you could upload it all to your Google Drive, set the folder as public and let anyone trawl through all your old tweets.

So, here?s almost six years of sciencebase on Twitter dating back to my first tweet in June 2007,?archived?and available for ?

		
			
			


			

			


	
		
Feb 22, 2013 

Meteorite map malarkey

			Posted at 8:13 am by David Bradley 
			?
As is obvious within a few seconds of having tweeted the map purportedly showing ?every meteorite that has hit Earth since 2300 BC?, the map actually just shows where the people are and where people have recorded meteorite impacts.



The first comment on the Gizmodo item puts this quite succinctly?.?It?s all the recorded meteorites. Not every meteorite. There?s a big difference.?The data would skew very ?

		
			
			


			

			


	
		
Feb 19, 2013 

Exercise, alcohol, fruit and veg

			Posted at 5:35 pm by David Bradley 
			?
There was a strike at the BBC yesterday, so the usual ?You and Yours? on Radio 4 was replaced with an annotated compilation of recent in-depth reports by Michael Moseley from past episodes (I believe). It made for an interesting alternative podcast listen on my dog-walk today. He discussed the high-intensity exercise regime he tried for Horizon last year, the ambiguity about alcohol units and whether smoothies and fruit juice count towards your ?5-a-day?.

In summary, ?

		
			
			


			

			


	
		
 
Five major challenges to avoid food crunch

			Posted at 9:00 am by David Bradley 
			?
Growing population and an increasing poverty gap are major challenges for global food security especially when the issue of biofuels produced from crops is introduced. According to Tahereh Alavi Hojjat of DeSales University, in Center Valley, Pennsylvania, USA, governments around the world must address five major challenges if we are not to see an enormous increase in human suffering, disease and starvation:

1 Energy security ? This directly affects food prices through fertiliser costs, farm energy ?

		
			
			


			

			


	
		
Feb 13, 2013 

Sciencebase grilled by students

			Posted at 8:00 am by David Bradley 
			?
UPDATE: 2012-02-13 It?s on again and this year I can offer a little advice on how to get a popular science book published if any students are interested in hearing my thoughts on that. Also, I?ve dropped the price for students on the PDF version of Deceived Wisdom for the next couple of days.

Once again, I?ll be attending the annual ?

		
			
			


			

			


	
		
Feb 4, 2013 

Supersonic ping pong ball

			Posted at 7:52 pm by David Bradley 
			?
What happens when a ping pong ball moving at supersonic speed hits a bat? This video, which is dripping college degrees, explains the physics and shows a few test shots. NO amount of wrist action can defeat supersonic?

Do not try this at home. I?m talking to you ?King Julian? 

		
			
			


			

			


	
		
		
			? Previous Page ? ? Previous entries			? Previous Page ? Next Page ?			Next entries ? ? Next Page ?

			Sciencebase Elsewhere

			Book Reviews

Fun skeptical stocking filler -- Andy Lewis, Quackometer



Starting to think of Bradley as the Bill Bryson of science writing -- Tony Davis, Elemensus



"Brilliant, funny, insightful, entertaining, readable" -- Kris Dyer, Audible


An excellent collection of science surprises -- Brian Clegg, Pop Sci

"Sometimes irreverent, but always intelligent"" -- The Guardian


"Clear, concise writing, backed up by an extensive knowledge" -- New Scientist


"The wide range of topics will appeal to science specialists and non-specialists alike" - BBC Online


"Bradley is one of the more approachable science voices on the web. He makes full use of the @ button to interact with fellow scientists and enthusiasts" -- The Independent


?David is probably the best science writer with whom I've had the pleasure to work. He is truly plug-and-play.? -- Randall C. Willis, Editor, American Chemical Society.


"A one-man New Scientist" -- Matthew Stibbe, Bad Language

title: Cwestiynau Ysgrifenedig a atebwyd - 2005
text:
Cwestiynau Ysgrifenedig a atebwyd - 2005Atebion a roddwyd i Gwestiynau Ysgrifenedig y Cynulliad i’w hateb ar 3 
Chwefror 2011 
 
[R] yn nodi bod yr Aelod wedi datgan buddiant. 
[W] yn nodi bod y cwestiwn wedi’i gyflwyno yn Gymraeg. 
 
Cynnwys 
2 Cwestiynau i'r Prif Weinidog 
 
3 Cwestiynau i'r Gweinidog dros Blant, Addysg a Dysgu Gydol Oes 
 
4 Cwestiynau i'r Dirprwy Brif Weinidog a'r Gweinidog dros yr Economi a Thrafnidiaeth 
4 Cwestiynau i’r Gweinidog dros Iechyd a Gwasanaethau Cymdeithasol 
 
4 Cwestiynau i'r Gweinidog dros Faterion Gwledig 
 
8 Cwestiynau i'r Gweinidog dros Gyfiawnder Cymdeithasol a Llywodraaeth Leol 
 
 
 Atebion a roddwyd i Gwestiynau Ysgrifenedig y Cynulliad i’w hateb ar 3 Chwefror 2011 
 
 
Gofyn i Brif Weinidog Cymru 
 
Nicholas Bourne (Canolbarth a Gorllewin Cymru): A wnaiff y Prif Weinidog restru holl argymhellion 
ymchwiliad Pennington i'r achosion o E.coli a fu yn 2005 a rhoi'r wybodaeth ddiweddaraf am gynnydd 
Llywodraeth Cynulliad Cymru o ran rhoi pob argymhelliad ar waith. (WAQ57028) 
 
Ni ddarparwyd cyfieithiad 
 
The recommendations of the Pennington Inquiry can be found at : 
 
http://wales.gov.uk/ecoliinquiry/?lang=en 
 
Only recommendations and 3, 16, 18 and 20 require action by the Welsh Assembly Government; progress 
is described below. 
 
Recommendation 3 - Additional resources should be made available to ensure that all food businesses in 
Wales understand and use the HACCP (Hazard Analysis, Critical Control Point) approach and have in 
place an effective, documented, food safety management system which is embedded in working culture 
and practice. 
 
I have asked the Food Standards Agency (FSA) to review food law enforcement procedures and 
structures in Wales.  The findings of this review will enable me to consider future resourcing options. 
 
 
Recommendation 16 - Businesses contracting for the supply of high-risk foods, such as raw and cooked 
meats, to public sector organisations must be subject to independent food hygiene audits. 
 
From September 2009 there has been a public sector framework agreement with a private company for 
the provision of third party hygiene audits.  The Welsh Assembly Government strongly encourages 
contracting authorities to follow this recommendation. 
Value Wales has also produced a ’ best practice 'framework' of food guidance for use by the public sector 
in Wales.  This aims to provide a structured approach to food procurement and has been developed in 
conjunction with the Food Standards Agency, WLGA, Trading Standards, other WAG departments and 
the Value Wales Food Group. 
The framework has been endorsed by the Chief Medical Officer, WLGA, FSA and Director General of 
Health & Social Services for Wales.   
 
 
Recommendation 18 - Every local authority should have a programme of audits to ensure that all schools 
have adequate toilet and hand washing facilities. 
 
Statutory responsibility for the provision of adequate school toilet facilities rests with local authorities.  
Not withstanding this, WAG is to issue good practice guidance to assist School Governing Bodies, Head 
Teachers and Local Authorities.  
 
A Stakeholder Steering Group has helped develop the guidance and the Consultation on the Best Practise 
Guidance on standards for school toilets was published in November 2010.  The consultation period 
ended on 24 January 2011 and included consulting with children and young people through the Pupil 
Voice Wales website and networks. Officials are now collating the responses and developing an action 
plan prior to the publication of the final guidance. 
 
 
 2 Atebion a roddwyd i Gwestiynau Ysgrifenedig y Cynulliad i’w hateb ar 3 Chwefror 2011 
 
Recommendation 20 - The National Assembly for Wales should consider my recommendations and 
monitor and report progress on implementation. 
 
On 7 July 2009, in plenary session, the then First Minister committed to reporting to the Assembly in 1 
year and regularly thereafter.  The Chief Medical Officer has agreed to act as the Welsh Assembly 
Government (WAG) ‘point of contact’ for the provision of updates to the First Minister and the Minister 
for Heath and Social Services.  I reported to the Assembly in October 2010. 
 
The Welsh Assembly Government will continue to monitor progress through routine reporting channels 
and with specific discussions when appropriate.  
 
 
I also refer you to the independent report published by Consumer Focus Wales in March 2010 at: 
http://www.consumerfocus.org.uk/wales/publications/protecting-consumers-from-e-coli-o157 
An updated report will be published by CFW in March 2011.   
 
 
 
Gofyn i’r Gweinidog dros Blant, Addysg a Dysgu Gydol Oes 
 
Nick Bourne (Canolbarth a Gorllewin Cymru): A wnaiff y Gweinidog egluro pam mae ei bolisïau'n 
methu gwella safonau yn ysgolion Cymru yn ôl y ffigurau diweddaraf gan y Sefydliad ar gyfer 
Cydweithrediad a Datblygiad Economaidd. (WAQ57031) 
 
Ni ddarparwyd cyfieithiad 
 
I have acknowledged that Wales’ results in PISA 2009 are extremely disappointing.  Whilst results within 
Wales have improved overall, there is clear evidence that, comparatively within the UK and 
internationally, the system is failing to consistently deliver good outcomes for our young people. 
My written statement on 2 February outlined the next steps I intend to take to drive up improvements 
throughout the education system. 
 
 
Nick Bourne (Canolbarth a Gorllewin Cymru): A wnaiff y Gweinidog egluro pa agweddau ar ei 
bolisïau sydd wedi arwain at y methiant mewn safonau academaidd a amlygwyd gan Estyn yn ei 
adroddiad a gyhoeddwyd ddydd Mawrth 25 Ionawr 2011. (WAQ57032)  
 
Ni ddarparwyd cyfieithiad 
 
My written statement on 2 February provided an outline of how we will tackle the challenges to drive up 
improvement across the education sector. 
 
 
Dai Lloyd (Gorllewin De Cymru): A wnaiff y Gweinidog ddatganiad am ohirio Cyfran 3 y Grantiau 
Gwella Adeiladau Ysgolion a Band A cyllid Ysgolion ar gyfer yr 21ain Ganrif am y 12 mis nesaf. 
(WAQ57039) 
 
Ni ddarparwyd cyfieithiad 
 
The Tranche 3 funding was announced in July 2010. The 13 projects `approved in principle’ indicated 
that spending would start in 2011-2012.  Following the budget announcement in November 2010 and the 
significant impact on capital budgets there is a need to manage these within the funding envelope 
available.  My officials are therefore working with Local Authorities (LAs) in order to ensure that the 
Assembly Government funding is made available at the right time, in line with the delivery of all projects.  
This may result in some projects starting at different times. 
 3 Atebion a roddwyd i Gwestiynau Ysgrifenedig y Cynulliad i’w hateb ar 3 Chwefror 2011 
 
Local Authorities submitted their 21st Century Schools Strategic Outline Programmes on 10th December 
2010.  These will now be assessed through a robust evaluation process, with an announcement in Summer 
2011.   
 
 
 
Gofyn i’r Gweinidog dros yr Economi a Thrafnidiaeth 
 
Mick Bates (Sir Drefaldwyn): Pwy fydd ar y panel arbenigol o arbenigwyr diwydiant a benodir i 
ddarparu cyngor yng nghyswllt Rhaglen Adfywio'r Economi. (WAQ57037) 
 
Ni ddarparwyd cyfieithiad 
 
The Creative Sector Panel has been in place since October 2010, and I announced details of the 
membership in a Written Cabinet Statement on 11 October 2010.  Membership of the remaining five 
Sector Panels is subject to the formal Public Appointments process.  Interviews have been carried out and 
recommendations for appointments made.  Once the successful candidates have accepted their 
appointments I will be in a position to issue a Written Cabinet Statement with full details of the Panel 
members and their backgrounds. 
 
 
 
Gofyn i’r Gweinidog dros Iechyd a Gwasanaethau Cymdeithasol 
 
Dai Lloyd (Gorllewin De Cymru): A wnaiff y Gweinidog ddatganiad am barhad posibl system 
annibynnol sy'n delio â chwynion i'r GIG ar ôl methu datrys y mater yn lleol. (WAQ57038) 
 
Ni ddarparwyd cyfieithiad 
 
I have taken the view that patients and staff will be better served by a more thorough and responsive 
process which seeks to resolve concerns as quickly as possible locally and which builds in elements of 
independence, for example, securing expert clinical advice, at those earlier stages.   
Under the arrangements I propose to bring into effect from 1 April, investment is being made in building 
skills and capacity locally to enable better handling of concerns.     
 
 
 
Gofyn i'r Gweinidog dros Faterion Gwledig  
 
Brynle Williams (Gogledd Cymru): A wnaiff y Gweinidog ddarparu manylion costau, hyd yn hyn, y 
gwaith i reoli Phytophthora Ramorum yng Nghymru. (WAQ57033) 
 
Ni ddarparwyd cyfieithiad 
 
Costs to date in respect of Phytophthora ramorum clearance are:  
  
£61,686 clearance of young crops   
£78,049 ground surveying and sampling  
£34,725 aerial surveying 
£1,000 to the private sector for assistance with agent’s fees. 
£586,080 over a period of 12 weeks on plant hire  
£76,000 civil engineering costs 
 
In addition, associated staff costs to date are £19,166.  
 
 4 Atebion a roddwyd i Gwestiynau Ysgrifenedig y Cynulliad i’w hateb ar 3 Chwefror 2011 
 
Brynle Williams (Gogledd Cymru): Hyd yn hyn, beth fu a) costau gweithredol yr adolygiad parhaus o 
fiwrocratiaeth ar y fferm, ac b) yr arbedion ariannol sydd wedi cael eu cyflawni gan yr adolygiad. 
(WAQ57034) 
 
Ni ddarparwyd cyfieithiad 
 
I refer you to the response I provided to WAQ 56082 (June 2010) which detailed costs totaling £2,626. In 
January of this year, two of my officials and Peredur Hughes, external advisor to the review, met with 
Richard Macdonald in London to discuss the DEFRA Farm Regulation Review and its linkages with our 
own review. The total operational costs of the ongoing review of on-farm red tape now stand at 
£2,762.50. 
The objectives of the Red Tape Review is to rationalize and reduce where possible bureaucracy for 
farmers and to improve communications with the industry. I do not have, and will not be able to obtain 
without a significant administrative overhead and financial cost, a figure for the financial savings that 
have been achieved on behalf of the industry and/or individual farmers in Wales.  
 
 
Brynle Williams (Gogledd Cymru): Pa drafodaethau y mae'r Gweinidog neu ei swyddogion wedi'u cael 
gyda chynrychiolwyr awdurdodau lleol ynghylch gwaredu daliadau amaethyddol cynghorau. 
(WAQ57035) 
 
Ni ddarparwyd cyfieithiad 
 
My officials have been in contact with local authorities to re-establish the Annual Report on Local 
Authority Smallholdings in Wales, which provides data on the disposal of local authority agricultural 
holdings. The 09/10 report, to which all local authorities contributed, was laid before the Assembly on 23 
December 2010.  While caution must be exercised when measuring minor differences and establishing 
trends  within such a small demographic, the continuation of the report will allow more accurate statistics 
to be collated and so present future trends to a higher degree of certainty.   
 
I will be providing a response to the recommendations of the Rural Development Sub-committee Inquiry 
into Local Authority Farms on the 7th February, which will include consideration of the the disposal of 
estate assets by local authorities. 
 
 
Brynle Williams (Gogledd Cymru): A wnaiff y Gweinidog ddarparu dadansoddiad o'r derbyniadau a

Mick Bates (Sir Drefaldwyn): A wnaiff y Gweinidog roi'r wybodaeth ddiweddaraf am ohebiaeth a 
thrafodaethau diweddar gyda Defra, ynghylch effaith setliad cyllido Defra ar awdurdodau lleol Cymru 
yng nghyswllt eu gweithgareddau gorfodi iechyd a lles anifeiliaid. (WAQ57040) 
 
Ni ddarparwyd cyfieithiad 
 
The budget for enforcement activity in Wales, as determined by DEFRA, has been set at £1.2 million for 
2011/12 and is additional to existing funding available to all Welsh local authorities via the Revenue 
Support Grant.  This figure has been communicated to the Welsh Local Government Association which 
has been informed that  this figure should be used for the purposes of planning enforcement activity. The 
exact mechanism for determining how the funding will be used and distributed is the subject of 
discussions between my officials and the WLGA.   This allocation is as a result of the recent UK 
Government Comprehensive Spending Review and is separate to the ongoing discussions regarding the 
devolution of animal health and welfare budgets to Wales.  
 
 
Mick Bates (Sir Drefaldwyn): Pa gynlluniau sydd gan y Gweinidog i sicrhau bod adran Iechyd 
Anifeiliaid Gwasanaeth Safonau Masnach Cyngor Sir Powys yn gallu parhau i ddarparu system effeithiol 
ar gyfer gorfodi iechyd a lles anifeiliaid. (WAQ57041) 
 
Ni ddarparwyd cyfieithiad 
 
The exact mechanism for determining how the funding will be used to provide effective animal health 
and welfare enforcement by each of the 22 local authorities in Wales is the subject of discussions between 
my officials and the WLGA. 
 
 
Mick Bates (Sir Drefaldwyn): Pa asesiad y mae'r Gweinidog wedi'i wneud o effaith setliad cyllido Defra 
ar adran Iechyd Anifeiliaid Gwasanaeth Safonau Masnach Cyngor Sir Powys. (WAQ57042) 
 
Ni ddarparwyd cyfieithiad 
 
The impact of the reduced funding settlement for Animal Health enforcement on all local authorities 
across Wales is, as yet, to be determined and will only become clear once decisions are taken in 
conjunction with the WLGA over the mechanism for distributing the allocation.

Gofyn i’r Gweinidog dros Gyfiawnder Cymdeithasol a Llywodraeth Leol 
 
Nick Bourne (Canolbarth a Gorllewin Cymru): Pa gynlluniau sydd gan y Gweinidog i weithredu 
menter 'Cymdeithas Fawr' yng Nghymru. (WAQ57029) 
 
Ni ddarparwyd cyfieithiad 
 
None. Putting people and communities is at the heart of our public services is at the core of our 
programme for public service improvement, and it always has been. This includes opportunities for 
volunteering and community involvement to develop skills and gain experience such as Gwirvol and 
 8 Atebion a roddwyd i Gwestiynau Ysgrifenedig y Cynulliad i’w hateb ar 3 Chwefror 2011 
 
Communities First; involving young people directly in the democratic process through Funky Dragon; 
and engaging citizens in Local Service Boards to design joined up services. 
 
Community engagement and involvement has, and will continue to be, a priority in Wales, we do not 
need to reinvent it as the ‘Big Society’ or ‘localism’.   
 
 
Nick Bourne (Canolbarth a Gorllewin Cymru): Pa drafodaethau y mae'r Gweinidog wedi'u cael gyda 
chyd-Weinidogion a Gweinidogion Llywodraeth y DU ynghylch y 'Gymdeithas Fawr' a'i goblygiadau i 
Gymru. (WAQ57030) 
 
Ni ddarparwyd cyfieithiad 
 
None, however I am due to meet with Wales Office Minister, David Jones MP, on 7th February. One of 
the issues we will be discussing will be the UK Government’s Big Society initiative. 
 
 9
