AGENDA ITEM NO. 2006/07/66   
 
 
 
 
WESTERN CHESHIRE PRIMARY CARE TRUST 
TRUST BOARD REPORT 
 
 
th
DATE OF BOARD MEETING: 28 March 2007 
  
TITLE OF REPORT: Practice Based Commissioning 
Governance Framework and Locally 
Enhanced Service proposal. 
  
PURPOSE OF REPORT: To establish structures and processes 
to enable Practice Based 
Commissioning in 2007-08. 
  
REPORT PREPARED BY: Graham Atkinson 
  
KEY POINTS/TEAM BRIEF: These arrangements support the GP 
Consortium and the PCT to work 
collaboratively on commissioning 
services across Western Cheshire 
PCT. 
 
These arrangements will establish 
100% fair shares budgets for all 
services at practice level. 
 
Practices will be paid 95p per 
registered patient for participating in 
PbC and supporting the production of 
a Consortium Commissioning Plan. 
 
Practices will be paid a further 95p 
per registered patient for achieving 
the objectives set out in the 
Consortium Commissioning Plan. 
  
RECOMMENDATION TO THE To adopt the proposed governance 
BOARD: arrangements and proposed format of 
the 2007-08 PbC Locally Enhanced 
Service. 
 
 
 
 1
Practice Based Commissioning Governance Framework and Locally Enhanced Service Proposal.  
Western Cheshire Primary Care Trust Board Meeting 
th
28 March 2007                          AGENDA ITEM NO. 2006/07/66   
 
 
 
RESOURCE IMPLICATIONS 
 
Resources are already identified in the LDP. 
 
IMPACT ON HEALTH INEQUALITIES INCLUDING HUMAN RIGHTS AND 
DIVERSITY 
  
Supports requirements placed on the PCT to commission services in-line with 
all guidance 
 
COMMUNICATIONS 
 
Supports improved communications between commissioners, providers and 
other stakeholders. 
 
PUBLIC AND PATIENT INVOLVEMENT 
 
Supports the involvement of patients and the public in commissioning 
decisions. 
 
INTEGRATED GOVERNANCE STANDARDS   
 
Please state: 
 
a) Which Corporate Objective this supports: 
 
 
? 
1.  To work with all partners to promote and protect the health and wellbeing 
of the population and to reduce health inequalities. 
 
? 
2.  To deliver a cost-effective, patient-led NHS in line with national policy and 
based on assessed health needs. 
 
? 
3.  To ensure that all services provided for the PCTs' residents comply with 
the Department of Health Standards for Better Health. 
 
? 
4.  To work with and develop our employed and contracted workforce in the 
implementation of future challenges and changes. 
 
? 
5.  To deliver ?value for money? within the available resources. 
 
b) Which Health Care Standard this supports: Clinical and cost 
 effectiveness. 
Governance 
 
c) Link / impact on Clinical Governance: 
 
Will ensure high standards of clinical governance in commissioned 
services. 
 
 
d) Risk number in Board Assurance Framework: 
 2
Practice Based Commissioning Governance Framework and Locally Enhanced Service Proposal.  
Western Cheshire Primary Care Trust Board Meeting 
th
28 March 2007                          AGENDA ITEM NO. 2006/07/66   
 
 
WESTERN CHESHIRE PRIMARY CARE TRUST 
 
Practice Based Commissioning Governance Framework 
2007-08 
 
?Commissioning is the process by which health needs of a population are 
assessed, and responsibility is taken for ensuring that appropriate services are 
available which meet these needs, (including delivery of national and local NHS 
Planning framework targets), and the accountability for the associated health 
outcomes is established.? 
 
1. INTRODUCTION 
 
This paper sets out the governance and accountability framework that the PCT has 
developed in order to support GP practices and the GP Consortium to commission 
services on behalf of their practice populations. 
 
Practice Based Commissioning will provide the following incentives for practices to 
improve and develop patient care in Primary and Community based settings.  
 
null To establish clinicians at the heart of the commissioning and service redesign. 
 
null To realise a real shift of focus to primary care delivery, through the utilisation of 
resources released through referral management and Payment by Results, into 
other local models of care. 
 
null To enable practices and localities to secure a wide range of services, including 
the development of primary care based services and services to support patients 
in self management of their health. 
 
null To enable the commissioning of integrated care pathways. 
 
null To enable practices to support people with long term conditions through 
investment in packages of community based care. 
 
null To use the experience gained by practices in the management of prescribing 
budgets to ensure the efficient use of existing resources. 
 
2. PRACTICE BASED COMMISSIONING GOVERNANCE FRAMEWORK  
 
This framework recognises the important role that practices should play in 
commissioning services for their patients and local populations and also sets out the 
parameters within the local heath system in which this will take place. 
 
The Framework for 2007-08 contains the following sections: 
 
? Corporate governance arrangements 
? The agreed local vision that Practice Based Commissioning will seek to achieve 
? The arrangements to develop and support sustainable clinical engagement 
? Roles and responsibilities of the PCT 
 3
Practice Based Commissioning Governance Framework and Locally Enhanced Service Proposal.  
Western Cheshire Primary Care Trust Board Meeting 
th
28 March 2007                          AGENDA ITEM NO. 2006/07/66   
? Roles and responsibilities of the practices 
? Finance and information 
? Business planning process and practice agreements 
? Public and patient involvement 
? Managing the potential conflict of practice commissioner and provider roles 
? Local dispute resolution process 
 
2.1 CORPORATE GOVERNANCE ARRANGEMENTS 
 
The PCT Practice Based Commissioning Governance Framework has been developed 
to support the PCT?s statutory duty of: 
 
? Being accountable for all funds allocated to it by the Secretary of State and 
for ensuring fair access to high quality services for its population, within its 
resource allocation; and 
? Involving and consulting patients and the public when considering new or 
different service provision 
 
?Corporate governance? is the system by which an organisation is directed and 
controlled, at its most senior levels, in order to achieve its objectives and meet the 
necessary standards of accountability and probity.  
 
Effective corporate governance, along with clinical governance, is essential to achieve 
clinical, quality and financial objectives. Fundamental to effective corporate governance 
is having the means to verify the effectiveness of this direction and control. 
 
The PCT Corporate Governance Framework currently requires compliance, by the PCT 
non-officer members, Board and Executive Committee members, officers and 
employees of the PCT, with the following key documents: 
 
? The accountable officer memorandum 
? The Codes of Conduct and Accountability issued by the Department of Health 
? Standing Orders as a framework for internal governance 
? Standing Financial Instructions as a framework for Financial  
 Governance 
 
Under this PCT Practice Based Commissioning Governance Framework, practices will 
also be required to comply with the above documents in order to ensure that the PCT 
remains compliant with its assurance framework responsibilities.  
 
In particular the Consortium or Practice Agreement will set out the terms under which 
practices are required to undertake their commissioning role. 
 
2.1.1 The Role of the Board 
 
The PCT Board will remain responsible for ensuring that this framework is robust in 
terms of meeting the PCT?s Corporate Governance responsibilities. 
 
The Framework will be underpinned by the business planning process, Consortium or 
Practice agreements and performance monitoring arrangements. 
 
 4
Practice Based Commissioning Governance Framework and Locally Enhanced Service Proposal.  
Western Cheshire Primary Care Trust Board Meeting 
th
28 March 2007                          AGENDA ITEM NO. 2006/07/66   
The Board will consider recommendations from the PEC through the Integrated 
Governance Committee before ratifying any budgets for 2007-08 or business plans.  
 
The Board must be assured that potential conflicts of interest are addressed, when for 
example; there are circumstances where the practice commissioner is also the provider 
of the service.   
 
The Board plays a crucial part in ensuring that patients and the public are integrally 
involved in the commissioning decisions made under PBC. 
 
The Board will receive regular progress reports in relation to the implementation of 
Practice Based Commissioning.  
 
2.1.2 The Role of the Integrated Governance Committee 
 
The Integrated Governance Committee will receive commissioning recommendations 
from the PEC and make recommendations to the Board relating to the implementation 
of the commissioning plans. 
 
2.1.3 The Role of the Professional Executive Committee 
 
The role of the Professional Executive Committee (PEC) is pivotal to the success of 
Practice Based Commissioning.  
 
The PEC plays a key part of the current Corporate Governance arrangements within 
the PCT and will therefore continue to give clinical advice to the Integrated Governance 
Committee and Board as part of the business planning process detailed within this 
framework. 
 
The PEC will receive regular progress reports in relation to the implementation of 
Practice Based Commissioning.  
 
2.1.4 The Role of the Local Medical Committee (LMC) 
 
The LMC has a role in supporting GMS and PMS practices in delivering their 
responsibilities in line with the Practice Based Commissioning Directed Enhanced 
Service.  
 
The LMC as a local representative committee does not have a governance role as part 
of the PCTs organisational governance structure for PbC. 
 
2.2. THE LOCAL VISION FOR PRACTICE BASED COMMISSIONING 
 
To improve the health of the people of Western Cheshire, through; 
 
? Securing improvement in health and reducing inequalities for the local 
population 
? Collective responsibility for achievement of National and Local targets by 
active engagement in effective demand management and service redesign. 
? Ensuring access to quality services. 
? Improving local access to services by providing care closer to home. 
? Developing a wider range of services more sensitive to local needs. 
? Achieving best value for money. 
 5
Practice Based Commissioning Governance Framework and Locally Enhanced Service Proposal.  
Western Cheshire Primary Care Trust Board Meeting 
th
28 March 2007                          AGENDA ITEM NO. 2006/07/66   
? Developing services in-line with evidence based practice and new 
technologies. 
? Developing the workforce. 
 
2.3. DEVELOPING AND SUPPORTING SUSTAINABLE CLINICAL ENGAGEMENT 
 
2.3.1. Structure 
 
Successful implementation of Practice Based Commissioning can only be achieved if 
robust structures are developed that will encourage and support local clinicians in 
becoming actively involved in the commissioning process. 
 
This framework seeks to achieve this by establishing arrangements that will enable all 
local clinicians to be part of the commissioning process, whilst recognising that there 
will be a number of levels of engagement. 
 
The PCT recognises that there are a number of models for the operation of Practice 
Based Commissioning. The PCT supports the national guidance and will support 
medical practices to work together to secure improvements in health services as part of 
a PCT-wide consortium. 
 
2.3.2 Wider Clinical Engagement  
 
During 2007-08 PbC will build on the effective engagement of GPs and medical 
practices from the previous year. Wherever possible nurses, allied health professionals, 
social care workers and other independent contractors (pharmacists, dentists and 
optometrists) should be engaged in the PbC agenda. Practice based commissioners 
should use local forums and representative committees to seek views and share 
business plans. 
 
2.3.3 Summary of Options  for Practice Engagement 
 
It is expected that all practices will take up the PbC Locally Enhanced Service (LES) in 
2007-08 and work together in a PCT-wide consortium with other practices to deliver 
Practice Based Commissioning, including the production of a single PCT-wide PbC 
plan. The LES payment will support the locality or consortia. The PCT will provide all 
practices with an indicative budget and feedback on its management of that budget, 
and the monthly information pack from the PCT on its use of resources. 
 
If an individual practice chooses not to take up the PbC LES the commissioning of 
services for the patients of the practice will be carried out by the PCT or by the PCT-
wide consortia. The PCT will still inform the practice of its indicative budget and provide 
the practice with a monthly information pack on its use of resources. 
 
2.4. ROLES AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF THE PCT 
 
Under the terms of this framework the PCT will have the following roles and 
responsibilities: 
 
? Involve local clinicians in setting a clear vision and strategy which achieves local 
and national targets as part of the Commissioning Prospectus and Local 
Delivery Planning cycles. 
 6
Practice Based Commissioning Governance Framework and Locally Enhanced Service Proposal.  
Western Cheshire Primary Care Trust Board Meeting 
th
28 March 2007                          AGENDA ITEM NO. 2006/07/66   
? Executive Directors of the PCT will retain delegated responsibility of the Board to 
achieve financial balance and manage financial risk. 
? Provide the infrastructure to support Practice Based Commissioning 
? Undertake a training needs analysis of practices to support their commissioning 
role and facilitate the appropriate training and development  
? Provide practices with monthly financial and activity information including 
benchmarked data with other practices within the PCT area and with the national 
average 
? Provide Public Health data to support commissioning 
? Support practice based commissioners in active engagement with the patients, 
the public and wider stakeholders in service redesign and the re-allocation of 
freed up resources 
? Approve practice business plans 
? Continue to commission those services outside the Consortium commissioning 
plan on behalf of GP practices. 
? Be responsible for the procurement of services through the preparation, 
negotiation, agreement and management of contracts/SLAs 
? Performance manage Practice/locality SLAs 
? Retain accountable body status for holding contracts/SLAs including legally 
binding Foundation Trust contracts 
? Routinely monitor the effectiveness of PBC and share good practice between 
practice/locality within the PCT area and outside 
? Support the practices/localities in engaging with local councils and social 
services in order to strengthen existing partnerships and support their 
commissioning role 
? Aim to resolve any disputes through the local resolution process 
? Intervene if it is apparent that the delivery of a key national target is threatened 
? Prepare monitoring reports for the PCT Board on the implementation of Practice 
Based Commissioning. 
 
2.5. ROLES AND RESPONSIBILITIES OF PRACTICES  
 
 Under the terms of this framework, practices, through the Consortium structure, have 
the following roles and responsibilities: 
 
? Develop a business plan, with guidance from the PCT  
? Contribute to the development of innovative ideas for service change through 
participation in the arrangements for clinical engagement that the PCT has 
established 
? Contribute to the management of demand for secondary care services 
? Review the activity and financial information provided by the PCT 
? Comply with the PCTs Corporate Governance Framework that includes 
adherence with the relevant statutory and non statutory standards 
? Commission in accordance with applicable Western Cheshire PCT 
Commissioning Policies  
? Utilise resources responsibly to ensure financial balance 
? Ensure that patients are able to exercise Choice 
? Contribute to delivering national and local targets  
? Ensure clinical changes do not adversely affect health inequalities within the 
PCT 
 7
Practice Based Commissioning Governance Framework and Locally Enhanced Service Proposal.  
Western Cheshire Primary Care Trust Board Meeting 
th
28 March 2007                          AGENDA ITEM NO. 2006/07/66   
? Ensure that the quality of services commissioned or provided by practices are 
underpinned by robust Clinical Governance arrangements and are evidenced 
based. 
? Ensure that pre-existing service level agreements and contracts, for example, 
those with the Independent Sector are honoured  
? Continue to prescribe in a clinical and cost effective way and ensure adherence 
to changes in local and national prescribing policy 
? Demonstrate a commitment to wider clinical engagement as detailed under 
paragraph 2.3.2. 
 
2.6. INFORMATION AND FINANCE 
 
2.6.1 Information 
 
The PCT will provide access to monthly information for practices during 2007-08.  
 
The format of the information provided will be developed with the Consortium and 
practices and an agreed version will be issued as soon as possible in 2007-08. The 
format of potential reports will be discussed at an early stage to ensure that data 
produced is meaningful and that an appropriate level of analysis has been undertaken. 
 
The PCT will: 
 
? produce information to facilitate the production of business plans   
? produce ongoing monitoring information 
? undertake basic checks to ensure that information is timely and accurate, 
working with practices where appropriate to validate data 
? carry out analysis of the information to ensure that exceptions to trends and 
outliers are identified, at a basic level 
 
In response practices will be expected to work with the PCT to: 
 
? review and understand the information produced 
? validate information where appropriate 
?  identify exceptions and trends 
? discuss possible reasons for the exceptions 
? judge whether changes in commissioning behaviour need to take place as a result. 
 
2.6.1.1 Validation of Information 
  
The validation checks carried out on the data will be documented and shared with 
practices.  
Practices will be expected to actively participate in the validation process, and will need 
to be satisfied that the information flows that underpin the commissioning process are 
of good quality and that issues are being actively addressed. 
 
The validation checks carried out on secondary care information by the PCT will 
include: 
 
? Highlighting activity variances from plan at speciality/HRG level.  
? Where there is significant activity with no plan, discuss with Provider  
? Checking allocation of GP practice codes  
 8
Practice Based Commissioning Governance Framework and Locally Enhanced Service Proposal.  
Western Cheshire Primary Care Trust Board Meeting 
th
28 March 2007                          AGENDA ITEM NO. 2006/07/66   
? Monitoring levels of uncoded episodes 
? Investigating significant changes in casemix.  
 
2.6.1.2. Investigating Exceptions 
 
The PCT already has routine systems in place with its main providers to raise issues 
around exceptions highlighted, data quality, timeliness of information flows, and to 
monitor progress. 
 
Further investigations will normally be carried out by the PCT on behalf of the 
practices/networks e.g. queries will be raised with the local Provider Units, progress 
documented and results reported. In some cases e.g. high cost - low volume cases, 
practices/localities may be expected to check against primary sources of information 
e.g. referral letters.  
 
Information queries should be directed to the PCT Knowledge Management 
Directorate, who will investigate and report back. This system will ensure that common 
themes are highlighted (eg several practices having a similar issues with information) 
and, in some cases, Knowledge Management Directorate staff will be able to answer 
queries without further referral onwards.  
 
 2.6.1.3 Benchmarking and Sharing of Information 
 
Benchmarking practice and locality information against PCT and national figures will be 
used to identify variances. Discussions at routine practice meetings will establish the 
reasons for results outside the expected range, and any further action or analysis. The 
PCT currently provides information that is practice (but not patient) identifiable. It is 
expected that patient identifiable data will be made available in early 2007-08. 
 
2.6.1.4 Systems and Data Sources  
 
Information from all providers will come into the PCT for onward circulation via monthly 
reports. 
 
Practice Based Commissioning contract monitoring will use the services provided by 
the County Information Shared Service Unit (CISSU) and by a shared data warehouse 
in the ICT shared services using the central Secondary User System (SUS) for 
secondary care activity. 
 
Activity information at HRG level will be based on the Contract Data Sets (CDS) 
produced by secondary care.  
 
The PCT will publish to practices the service level agreement it has with CISSU and the 
ICT shared service in respect of the timing and quality of reports. 
 
2.6.2 Budget Setting and Financial Management 
 
The PCT is proposing to provide indicative budgets to practices as soon as possible in 
2007-08 for the following areas of the PCT?s expenditure: 
 
? Payment by Results (PbR) activity for the major provider Trusts. 
? Mental Health services 
? Secondary care services currently outside the scope of PbR 
 9
Practice Based Commissioning Governance Framework and Locally Enhanced Service Proposal.  
Western Cheshire Primary Care Trust Board Meeting 
th
28 March 2007                          AGENDA ITEM NO. 2006/07/66   
? Community nursing services 
? Services provided by Allied Health professionals 
? Services currently provided by other local PCTs (e.g. School Nursing) 
? Services provided by the Independent Sector 
? PDS and GDS dental services 
? Community pharmacy services 
? GP prescribing 
 
Practice Based Commissioning exclusions 
 
A number of services have been specifically excluded from the practice indicative 
budgets, as per the latest Practice Based Commissioning Guidance, as follows: 
 
? Core GMS and PMS 
? Specialised services, services commissioned regionally and nationally and 
national screening programmes. 
 
PbR activity for other Provider Trusts is excluded at this stage as volumes for individual 
practices are comparatively low and minor swings in referral patterns could affect 
practice budgetary performance adversely. 
 
Services commissioned by PCTs from other primary care providers (dentists, 
community pharmacists and optometrists) and secondary care referrals by primary care 
dentists or optometrists cannot be changed without full consultation and the consent of 
other professionals. 
 
Allocation of budgets, including payment by Results (PbR) activity and prescribing 
 
Practice budgets for all services will be allocated to individual practices based on a 
weighted capitation (fair shares) methodology, as recommended by the Department of 
Health. 
 
2.6.2.1 Presentation of budget information 
 
The PCT will develop the presentation of budget information in conjunction with the 
Consortium and Practices, so that it can be presented in a concise and understandable 
format, which will enable practices to identify variances from planned activity.  This 
information will be developed in parallel with the activity information pack being 
prepared by the PCT Knowledge Management Department. 
 
2.6.2.3 Financial Management  
 
The PCT sees financial management as a year-round process and not a year-end 
process.  
 
Regular monitoring (using trigger points, referral ceilings and floors) will highlight 
potential problems early and a pro-active course of action will be agreed with any 
practices/locality indicating potential year-end overspends against the indicative 
budgets.  
 
Where a practice or locality  puts forward a plan to spend more in one year to free up 
resources in future years (ie. achieve financial balance over a three-year period), the 
 10
Practice Based Commissioning Governance Framework and Locally Enhanced Service Proposal.  
Western Cheshire Primary Care Trust Board Meeting 
th
28 March 2007                          AGENDA ITEM NO. 2006/07/66   
PCT will consider this as part of their wider financial responsibilities but the first priority 
must be to ensure balance at year-end. 
 
A PCT-wide risk-sharing pool to handle high cost individual care or unplanned in year 
variations in activity and cost will be established.  Department of Health guidance refers 
to a top-sliced fund of between 3% and 5% of indicative budgets.  The PCT intends to 
develop a list of high cost, low volume HRGs for which practices can apply to have their 
activity funded from the risk-sharing pool.  The budget for these specific HRGs will be 
top-sliced from individual practice budgets based on historic activity levels.  All PbR 
activity outside of this prescribed list will be attributed to practice budgets. 
 
Freed up resources can be used by practices on premises development only with the 
specific approval of the PCT. 
 
The first part of the LES payment (95p per registered patient) is payable to the practice 
on production of a Consortium Practice Based Commissioning plan agreed between 
the Consortium and the PCT. This payment is to support its involvement in Practice 
Based Commissioning.  
 
The second part of the LES payment (a minimum of 95p per registered payment) is 
payable if the practice achieves the objectives set out in the plan, and should be paid 
from the resources that the plan will have released against the total indicative budget 
held by the practice. These monies are intended for reinvestment in patient care or 
other practice activity that supports the delivery of plan objectives. 
 
If the plan releases more resources than are needed to pay the second LES payment, 
then the practice and Consortium would be entitled to redirect resources into services 
via an agreed commissioning plan, for the benefits of patients for up to 70% of these 
resources. The PCT would use the remaining 30% to meet wider needs across the 
PCT area. 
 
It is worth noting that if a practice delivers all the objectives set out in the plan agreed 
with the PCT, but the resources freed up do not cover the second LES payment, then 
the practice may still be entitled to the second LES payment in full. The PCT when 
agreeing plans will ensure that they are robust in identifying achievable levels of freed-
up resources. 
 
The Department of Health?s intention is that 30% of freed up resources should be used 
by the PCT to meet a wider health need across the whole PCT area. Where a PCT is in 
deficit at year-end, the first call on the 30% will be to cover such overspends but only 
as a last resort. 
Where practices free up resources above the second LES component, they can agree 
with the PCT a greater value of freed up resources to be reinvested in patient care. 
 
2.6.2.4 Support for Practices 
 
The first component of the LES will be payable to practices agreeing to take part in 
PbC in 2007-8 and assist the production of a Consortium commissioning plan. 
 
The second component of the LES will, on delivery of the plan by 31 March 2008, be 
payable when the PCT year end position is determined.  
 
 
 11
Practice Based Commissioning Governance Framework and Locally Enhanced Service Proposal.  
Western Cheshire Primary Care Trust Board Meeting 
th
28 March 2007                          AGENDA ITEM NO. 2006/07/66   
 
2.7. BUSINESS PLANNING PROCESS 
 
The Consortium and practices will complete the business plan as commissioners of 
services and not as providers. 
 
Business plans, once approved by the PCT, will then form the basis of a 
PCT/Consortium/practice agreement. 
 
2.8.  PUBLIC AND PATIENT INVOLVEMENT 
 
The Primary Care Trust acknowledges the importance of getting patients involved in 
practice-based commissioning, as law (Health and Social Care Act 2001. Chapter 15. 
Section 11.1) now requires public involvement and consultation.  It is the legal duty of 
all health service commissioners to ensure that ?persons to whom those services are 
being or may be provided are, directly or through representatives, involved in and 
consulted on the planning of those services, the development and consideration of 
proposals for changes in the way those services are provided and decisions affecting 
the operation of those services?.  In response to this legal requirement, in 2007-08, the 
Primary Care Trust will ask all practice-based commissioners (whether working 
independently or in a locality or consortia) to outline within the Practice Based 
Commissioning Plan their arrangements for seeking the views of and engaging with 
their patients and the public. The implementation of these plans will form part of the 
judgement from the PCT on the success of the PBC commissioner development plans. 
The PCT, Consortium and practices should consider how to use practice patients 
forums and PPI infrastructures that the PCT have in place already as and new and 
innovative ways of engaging local patients. 
 
2.8.1 Patient Surveys 
 
Each of the GP practices undertakes an annual patient survey, as do many of the PCT 
clinical services. The results and findings from these surveys can provide intelligence 
on local people's perception of services.  There will also be opportunities to develop 
surveys relating to issues identified by locality business plans. 
 
2.8.2 Practice Based Patient Groups 
 
Some of the PCT's practices have patient groups; with support offered to the remaining 
practices should they wish to develop one.  This provides a practice-focused group of 
people who can be asked their views about local services and improvements that can 
feed directly in to the PBC agenda. 
 
2.8.3 Patient and Public Involvement (PPI) Forum 
 
The PCT has developed a constructive working relationship with the PCT PPI Forum, 
and worked jointly with them on several initiatives.  The PCT PPI lead will keep the 
Forum informed about the development of Practice Based Commissioning business 
plans. 
 
2.8.4 Health Equalities Overview and Scrutiny Committee 
 
Where Business plans propose a 'substantial variation' to current service provision the 
plans will need to be shared and discussed with the Cheshire County Council Overview 
 12
Practice Based Commissioning Governance Framework and Locally Enhanced Service Proposal.  
Western Cheshire Primary Care Trust Board Meeting 
th
28 March 2007                          AGENDA ITEM NO. 2006/07/66   
and Scrutiny Committee. The PCT has developed a working relationship with the 
Overview and Scrutiny Committee and will support practices/localities with this process. 
 
2.9 MANAGING THE POTENTIAL CONFLICT OF PRACTICE COMMISSIONER AND 
PROVIDER ROLES 
 
Business plans should be developed on the basis of clinicians commissioning services 
on behalf of their practice populations and not as potential providers of services. 
 
Clinical engagement in the identification of health needs and the proposals for service 
redesign is crucial to the success of Practice Based Commissioning. Clinical 
involvement in developing service specifications is also important to ensure that the 
PCT procures the right level and type of service. 
 
It is however highly likely that local clinicians either on a practice or consortia basis will 
wish to extend their provider role in response to local business plans. 
 
In order to manage any potential conflicts of interest and avoid legal challenges, the 
PCT will undertake the procurement and performance management of contracts, 
involving appropriate clinical input. This will be conducted in line with the PCT Standing 
Financial Instructions (SFI) and the guidance issued by the NHS Purchasing and 
Supply Agency.  
 
 13
Practice Based Commissioning Governance Framework and Locally Enhanced Service Proposal.  
Western Cheshire Primary Care Trust Board Meeting 
th
28 March 2007                          AGENDA ITEM NO. 2006/07/66   
3. REVIEW 
 
This framework has been developed to support Practice Based Commissioning across 
Western Cheshire PCT during 2007-08 and will be reviewed in the light of: 
? local issues that need to be addressed or clarified during that time  
? in response to Department of Health guidance where appropriate 
 
 14
Practice Based Commissioning Governance Framework and Locally Enhanced Service Proposal.  
Western Cheshire Primary Care Trust Board Meeting 
th
28 March 2007

title: Business Reviews & Diagnostics
text:
Business Reviews & DiagnosticsPrint to PDF File | Return to Non-Print Version

When you focus on the day-to-day running of your business, it is vital to review your progress on a regular basis and to think about longer term and more strategic issues.

Reviewing your progress will be particularly useful if you feel:

	Uncertain of how well the business is performing 
	Unsure if you are getting the most out of the business or the market opportunities 
	You have not updated your business plan since starting to trade 
	You need to reassess your core activities, efficiency and your financial position 
	Your business is moving in a direction different to the one you had planned 
	You need to redefine your business goals 


A Business Diagnostic Review with a Venture Wales adviser enables you to take control of your business and work out the best way in which we can help you. We can give you support in addressing the above points and also in planning the growth of your business, finding new customers, raising finance, developing the skills of your employees and helping you to find the information you need on a range of topics.

We have performed a substantial number of reviews for many companies across all industry sectors. These independent reviews are undertaken by experienced business professionals and offer clients an impartial view on the current status of their business.

Our approach is based upon a Balanced Scorecard appraisal. We review the whole business entity , : the business ?s Vision and its overall strategy, as well as the functional strategies to achieve the Vision. It also includes an independent objective review of both the external and internal factors impacting the business.

	From the Business Diagnostics Review the client receives a detailed report along with key recommendations and an action plan with timescales to address the identified key business issues. This Action Plan also signposts the client to any relevant external business organisations for support and assistance.


This Business Diagnostics Review process has benefited many businesses by identifying, addressing and focusing on their key business issues, enabling them to become more competitive and have a sustainable future.

The initial Business Review is free, and you can use it to discuss your detailed requirements and work out a tailored support package to meet your needs.

For further information please call?Paul Evans ?on 01443 742888.
 
Print to PDF File | Return to Non-Print Version
Business Reviews & Diagnostics

Nadolig Llawen 
a Blwyddyn Newydd Dda
Edrych yn ?l dros dair blynedd o Brifysgol Cymru ar ei newydd wedd
Mae?n anodd credu, ond mae tair blynedd wedi mynd ers i Brifysgol Cymru gael ei 
hailgyfansoddi. Bu?n gyfnod hynod brysur - yr adfyfyrio gofalus, beirniadol a?r cynllunio 
strategol i ddechrau, ac yn dilyn hynny, buddsoddi a gweithredu i atgyfnerthu sefyllfa?r 
Brifysgol fel sefydliad cynaliadwy sy?n cyfoethogi bywyd cenedlaethol Cymru. Dros y 
deuddeg mis diwethaf neilltuwyd llawer o amser ac ymdrech yn gweithredu strwythur 
academaidd newydd y Brifysgol, a pharatoi ar gyfer yr Adolygiad Sefydliadol a gynhaliwyd 
gan yr Asiantaeth Sicrhau Ansawdd yn yr hydref.
Ymysg y buddsoddiadau sylweddol iawn a wnaed gan y Brifysgol roedd cyllid ar gyfer 
prosiectau amrywiol megis rhaglen ryngwladol Ysgoloriaethau Arloesi Tywysog Cymru; creu 
Cadeiriau Ymchwil Prifysgol Cymru sydd wedi?u lleoli mewn sefydliadau prifysgol Cymreig 
a Llyfrgell Genedlaethol Cymru; datblygu presenoldeb gwe rhyngweithiol i wasanaethu 
anghenion ein myfyrwyr, staff a chyn-fyfyrwyr ledled y byd; penodi tri Dirprwy Is-
Ganghellor ac am y tro cyntaf, creu Cyfadran Academaidd i?r Brifysgol, y mae ei thri Deon 
a saith Uwch-ddarlithydd wedi dechrau ar y gwaith o angori gweithrediadau rhyngwladol y 
Brifysgol.
Mae?r egni a?r dalent a gyfrannwyd gan ein staff wedi arwain at gynnydd rhagorol yn ystod y flwyddyn ddiwethaf, yn enwedig 
yn y broses o ddatblygu?r Strwythur Llywodraethu Academaidd a Fframwaith Academaidd Cyffredin newydd ar gyfer graddau 
ymchwil (gyda?r olaf yn cael ei gwblhau mewn cydweithrediad ? sefydliadau eraill y Gynghrair). Rydym wedi dathlu hanner can 
mlynedd o gynadleddau a gweithdai addysgol yng Ngregynog, wedi dyfarnu Cymrodoriaethau Addysgu cyntaf Prifysgol Cymru 
ac wedi croesawu t?m Cyswllt Myfyrwyr newydd. Mae?r Brifysgol hefyd yn falch o fod yn yrrwr allweddol wrth sefydlu dau brosiect 
mawr newydd: y Gymdeithas Ddysgedig i Gymru a Chyfrifiadura Perfformiad Uchel Cymru.
Fel y byddwch yn sylwi, mae bron pob un o?r gweithgareddau hyn yn ymwneud ? chreu sylfaen gadarn ar gyfer gwaith pellach, 
gan addo dyfodol prysur a chynhyrchiol - a digon o waith yn 2011. Yn y cyfamser hoffwn ddymuno egwyl braf i chi dros y Nadolig 
a Blwyddyn Newydd dda iawn.
Yr Athro Marc Clement, Is-Ganghellor
Ar y gweill....
14 ? 16 Rhagfyr:  Cynhadledd Ymchwil Flynyddol SRHE ? Casnewydd
16 Rhagfyr:  Seminar lFHE: Determining the Educational Character: What is the role of the Governing Body? - Llundain
I?ch dyddiadur
11 Ionawr:  Gr?p Diddordeb Arbennig Profiad Ymgeisydd yr AUA - Manceinion
18 Ionawr:  Cyfarfod UWASF - Wrecsam
1Myfyrio am gydnabod cyflawniadau myfyrwyr
Y mis diwethaf fe dreuliais i ddiwrnod yn yr Amwythig mewn seminar o?r enw Recognition, the Diploma Supplement and HEAR. 
Roedd yn canolbwyntio ar gyflwyno ideolegau ac arferion Atodiadau Diploma a?r Adroddiad Cyrhaeddiad Addysg Uwch (HEAR).  
Mynegodd nifer o siaradwyr, gan gynnwys Mr Huw Morris, Cofrestrydd Academaidd Prifysgol Abertawe, fanteision Atodiadau 
Diploma a?r enw da a geir o fod yn ddeiliad llabed Atodiad Diploma.
Roedd enghreifftiau o Brifysgol Bournemouth yn dystiolaeth bellach o gadernid Atodiadau Diploma a?u goblygiadau i waith 
sicrhau ansawdd yn y sector. Roedd y rhain yn cynnwys astudiaeth arolwg am ymwybyddiaeth myfyrwyr a chyflogwyr o 
Atodiadau Diploma, oedd yn dangos y bwlch cyfathrebu rhwng ymarferwyr a rhanddeiliaid. Er ein bod wedi clywed y byddai 
deunyddiau hyrwyddo ar gael yn y dyfodol agos iawn, bydd angen dilysu effeithiau?r deunyddiau hyn mewn astudiaethau yn 
y dyfodol. Mae hyn o ddiddordeb penodol i mi oherwydd mae?n dangos y diffyg cyfathrebu sydd rhwng gweithredwyr a rhan-
ddeiliaid yn y sector. Mae?n sicr yn ystyriaeth bwysig i Brifysgol Cymru wrth iddi barhau ??i hymdrechion i ymglymu ??i myfyrwyr 
ac astudio?r heriau o sicrhau tystiolaeth o gywerthedd academaidd.
Cafwyd cryn drafod am gyflwyno HEAR ymysg cyfranogwyr y seminar, oedd yn cynnwys gweinyddwyr o brifysgolion Cymru a 
Lloegr. Er gwaethaf barn datblygwr y Ganolfan Cofnodi Cyflawniad, fod HEAR 
yn fwy cynhwysfawr nag Atodiadau Diploma, roedd llawer o gyfranogwyr yn 
mynegi pryder a oedd yn  gydnaws yng nghyd-destun addysg ryngwladol/fyd-
eang.
Yn gyffredinol, roedd y seminar yn codi syniadau newydd am ddulliau o 
gyflawni cydnabyddiaeth. Bydd trafodaethau am y gwahaniaethau rhwng 
HEAR ac Atodiadau Diploma yn parhau hyd nes y bydd materion cydnawsedd 
wedi?u datrys. Mae?n ymddangos bod datblygiad HEAR a?i r?l yn y sector 
addysg uwch yn aneglur, ond mae?n bendant werth cadw golwg ar y sefyllfa.
Dr Chung-Hsuan Greg Liang
Rhwydwaith Myfyrwyr Llundain
Un o?r canfyddiadau allweddol o ymdrechion y llynedd i gyfathrebu?n fwy effeithiol gyda?n 
myfyrwyr oedd bod myfyrwyr yn ein canolfannau cydweithredol yn dymuno cael mwy o 
fewnbwn i siapio eu profiad addysgol, ynghyd ? gwell cyfleoedd ymglymu. I fynd i?r afael ? hyn, 
mae?r t?m cyswllt myfyrwyr wedi sefydlu Rhwydwaith Myfyrwyr Llundain i ddod ? myfyrwyr sy?n 
astudio am ddyfarniadau Prifysgol Cymru yn un o?r 17 canolfan gydweithredol yn ardal Llundain 
at ei gilydd.
 
Y syniad yw creu llais unedig a fydd yn rhoi adborth i ni o brofiad dysgu?r myfyriwr yn y rhan-
barth hwn. Hefyd rydym ni am helpu ein cynrychiolwyr o blith y myfyrwyr o?r canolfannau hyn i 
ffurfio rhwydwaith a allai helpu i gefnogi hyfforddiant perthnasol ar gyfer y math hwn o weith-
garedd. Fel rhan o hyn, cynhaliwyd ein cyfarfod cyntaf ddydd Mercher 24 Tachwedd a threuliodd 
myfyrwyr o?r canolfannau cydweithredol yn Llundain y dydd gyda?r t?m cyswllt myfyrwyr, ein 
llyfrgellydd, Ms Bronwen Blatchford ac yn bwysicaf oll, ei gilydd.  
Cafwyd trafodaethau helaeth, oedd yn cwmpasu amrywiaeth o bynciau, gan gynnwys sut i 
wneud y defnydd gorau o?r cyfleusterau llyfrgell ar-lein a?r gwahanol fathau o adborth 
myfyrwyr sydd ar gael. Gadawodd llawer o?r cyfranogwyr ? chynlluniau gweithredu ar gyfer 
datblygu a gwella?r dulliau adborth yn eu sefydliadau.
 
Yn gyffredinol, roedd yn ddigwyddiad llwyddiannus a difyr. Casglwyd adborth da a fydd o fudd i 
PC wrth ddatblygu ac rydym ni?n awyddus i ddechrau cynllunio?r cyfarfod nesaf yn Llundain, ym 
mis Chwefror 2011.                                                                                                                          Rhys Parry
Diolch am eich cyfraniadau 
Yn rhifyn mis Ionawr:
a?ch adborth.
Digwyddiad sefydlu i safonwyr 
Cadwch mewn cysylltiad ? ni: 
ac arholwyr allanol
newyddionansawdd@cymru.ac.uk
Y mae?n bosibl cael copi o destun y cyhoeddiad hwn mewn  
gwahanol ffurfiau: cysylltwch ??r Brifysgol os gwelwch yn dda.
Cynhyrchir Newyddion Ansawdd gan John McInally, Helen Knifton a Wing Tsz Chow, ac fe?i golygir gan Wing Tsz Chow.

                            Rugby hamstring injuries under spotlight in new research

Hamstring problems among sports men and women are very common but now new research from the University could help prevent top rugby union stars picking up the injury.

The study, involving elite English Premiership clubs and the senior England team, aims to identify how clubs currently treat and prevent hamstring injuries among their players - and to suggest new methods of preparing players in the future to minimise the chances of picking up hamstring problems.

Sadie Jones, a lecturer and PhD researcher at the University's Centre for Sports Studies, is carrying out the research in conjunction with top clubs such as Gloucester, Saracens and Wasps as well as the Rugby Football Union (RFU), the sport?s governing body.

'Little detail is known about current practice in the prevention and treatment of hamstring injuries in elite English rugby union and there does not appear to be consensus as to what constitutes best practice,' she said.

'I'll be working with all the Premiership Rugby Union clubs to gather data on the management of hamstring injuries but it is already clear that they represent a major concern.

'The research will involved talking to doctors, physiotherapists and strength and conditioning specialists to build the first-ever comprehensive audit of current treatment and prevention practice. From this audit, I will aim to provide suggestions for a best practice approach to prevention.' 



 





Contact: pressoffice@kent.ac.uk

Story published at 10:02am 4 May 2011

Unique Industrial Artwork Wins Heritage Lottery Fund Support

Launch Date: 2012-01-26  

Press release:

 


The Heritage Lottery Fund (HLF) has awarded £46,700 to the Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historical Monuments of Wales to acquire a unique collection of over 600 original drawings and watercolours by Falcon Hildred, the Wales-based artist. The Royal Commission, based in Aberystwyth, is working in partnership with the Ironbridge Gorge Museum Trust (IGMT) to save this outstanding visual record of industrial buildings and townscapes for future generations.






With the help of volunteers, the collection has been catalogued, and high-quality scanning will ensure that superb digital images will be available online through Coflein (the Royal Commission’s online database), and both the Ironbridge and People’s Collection Wales websites. In addition, exhibitions, public talks and an authoritative publication are planned for 2012 to further publicise the collection.






Falcon Hildred is a highly accomplished artist who has dedicated his working life to recording the buildings and landscapes of nineteenth-and twentieth-century industry, producing works of high aesthetic, historic and social value. He has recorded in detail technological and engineering change and a rapidly disappearing way of life. The drawings record Blaenau Ffestiniog (the artist’s home since 1969 and a place he has recorded extensively), and a number of industrial towns in Wales and England. These include Cardiff, Newport and Swansea, as well as Grimsby, Coventry, London and Birmingham.  






A major exhibition of selected originals will run from late September 2012 to April 2013 in the Coalbrookdale Gallery at Ironbridge with further touring exhibitions being planned from 2013 onwards. Digital versions of the exhibition will be shown at the Royal Welsh Show and the National Eisteddfod in 2013. A book highlighting the significance of the collection and the artist will be published in September 2012. This publication and the research for it will be the basis for a series of new educational and outreach sessions at Ironbridge led by the Museum’s education staff and their volunteers. Educational material will also be generated for the People’s Collection Wales website.






Commenting on the award, Peter Wakelin, Secretary of the Royal Commission, said “The acquisition of this collection represents a lifetime’s recording work being safeguarded for the future. Falcon Hildred gives us inspiring new ways of looking at historic buildings and landscapes that readily engage everyone from small children to architects and heritage experts. It is great news that this fantastic resource will be now available to all in perpetuity.” 






Explaining the importance of the HLF support, Steve Miller, CEO of the Ironbridge Gorge Museum Trust said “We are immensely grateful to the Heritage Lottery Fund for their support in acquiring this amazing collection.  We are looking forward to working with the Royal Commission to ensure that as many people as possible can enjoy the work of a brilliant and unique artist whose documenting of the industrial age is truly breath-taking”.  






Notes to Editors:




The Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historical Monuments of Wales is the investigation body and national archive for the historic environment of Wales. It has the lead role in ensuring that Wales’s archaeological, built and maritime heritage is authoritatively recorded, and seeks to promote the understanding and appreciation of this heritage nationally and internationally. 




Website: www.rcahmw.gov.uk






Ironbridge Gorge Museum Trust (IGMT) is one of the largest independent museums in the world and cares for 10 museums within the Ironbridge Gorge, one of the United Kingdom’s first World Heritage Sites.  Ironbridge has an international reputation for its care and interpretation of the industrial buildings and monuments in what is known as the Birthplace of the Industrial Revolution.




Website:www.ironbridge.org.uk






About the Heritage Lottery Fund




Using money raised through the National Lottery, the Heritage Lottery Fund (HLF) sustains and transforms a wide range of heritage for present and future generations to take part in, learn from and enjoy. From museums, parks and historic places to archaeology, natural environment and cultural traditions, we invest in every part of our diverse heritage. HLF has supported over 30.000 projects, allocating £4.6billion across the uk.




Website:  www.hlf.org.uk






For further information, images and interviews, please contact




Nicola Roberts, The Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historical Monuments of Wales  nicola.roberts@rcahmw.gov.uk  Telephone:- 01970 621248

title: Case study list
text:
Case study list
  
    	Home
	Good Practice Exchange
	Case studies
	Case study list
	Case study list


  


  Case study list


  
    Delivering the health benefits of walking in Communities First areas in Denbighshire

  


  
    Denbigshire County Council


    02/10/2008


    
      The health benefits of walking represent one of the primary advantages of the public making greater use of the countryside. The Walking Your Way to Health initiative aimed to improve health through the promotion of regular brisk walking.

    


    Its initial focus was on older people and those with cardiac problems, primarily in Community First areas. The funding partners were CCW, the New Opportunities Fund, the Assembly Government and the British Heart Foundation. Local Authorities take the lead in forming local partnerships.


    The Walking Your Way to Health initiative in Denbighshire, known as Footloose, is a programme of led walks of 30 minutes and over, with a primary focus on inactive and/or socially isolated individuals. The local partnership, set up at the start to run the programme included Denbighshire County Council who managed the project, Denbighshire Local Health Board, National Public Health Service and Conwy & Denbighshire NHS Trust. The scheme started by targeting Rhyl and, in particular, the two Communities First areas in the town. The scheme expanded into a deprived ward area of Denbigh and then through groups and organisations into other areas of Denbighshire.


    A team of 45 trained volunteers lead the walks in their local area. By the end of the three year scheme (the scheme ended in December 2006), 2636 different individuals took part in 681 programmed guided walks. In total there were 13526 participants. Other organisations also took part in the scheme and requested training so that they could lead their own walks. These included the Local Health Board who launched lunchtime walks from St Asaph Business Park and Stanley Hospital. These 'custom' walks accounted for over 4500 participants. Denbighshire County Council has distributed 35,000 self-guided walk leaflets and has logged 133 features about the project in the local media over the 3 years. Other features of the initiative included an incentive scheme to encourage regular walking, GP awareness-raising events and special longer walks.


    The scheme is hoping to continue with new funding under the Sports Council for Wales, Let's Walk Cymru initiative. However, the scheme could operate on a smaller scale through the network of volunteer leaders but this will be less successful as the co-ordinator role is vital for continuity, motivation and development.


    The key features for success of the scheme included partnership working, a full time co-ordinator, the targeting of groups in or at risk of poor health and the use of volunteers.


    
      Contact Name Katrina Day

      Contact_Role Footloose coordinator

      Contact Telephone 01745 356197

      Contact Email Katrina.day@denbighshire.gov.uk

      Contact Address Denbighshire County Council

      County Hall

      Wynnstay Road

      Ruthin

      LL15 1YN 

      Website www.denbighshire.gov.uk

WORDS: Ben Sainty (Youth Editorial Group)
Cardiff Blues 58 Connact 0

Friday's?match between the Cardiff Blues and Connacht was a very one-sided game, with the Blues trashing Connacht 58-0.

The first half is where the action was; the first?ten minites of the game was a bit slow with a lot of kicking back and fore and a few mistakes that slowed the game down,?although?the first try came pretty quickly from Jaime Roberts at?seven minutes. After that it took a little while before the rest of the tries came bowling in,?and a massive?six more were scored, bringing the first half try total for the Blues?to seven.

The second half was slower, and a lot looser.?Since the game was already won the Blues just tried to open things up and throw the ball. They kept up a good solid defence at all times and made sure nothing got past them. One try was scored by the prop Taufa'ao Filise which was converted to take the score to 58-0. With this win they have broken the Magners league record of most ammount of points difference in a match.

Overall it was a good solid performance from the Blues, with hints of what they can do when they are at their best.

title: Microsoft Word - Item 6.2 Community Strategyv2.doc
text:
Microsoft Word - Item 6.2 Community Strategyv2.doc 
 
 
Meeting of South Gloucestershire Primary Care Trust Board 
To be held on: Wednesday 23rd June 2010 
Location: NHS South Gloucestershire, 8 Brook Office Park, Emersons Green 
 
 
Agenda item: 6.2 
South Gloucestershire���s Sustainable Community Strategy 
1 Purpose 
 
This paper presents a summary review of the Consultation Draft of the SCS on behalf of the 
PCT. A copy of the Consultation Draft was circulated to Board members two weeks ago. The 
SCS has been produced by the South Gloucestershire Partnership (SGP). The present 
Consultation Draft already incorporates several comments which were fed back following the 
initial stage of the review. 
 
The focus of the review has been to ensure that health aspects are well represented in the 
strategy and that the commitments placed on the PCT are appropriate. The review consists of 
the high-level comments presented here and a more detailed set of marked-up comments 
including editorial comments.  
 
2 Recommendations 
 
The Board are asked to agree the high-level review for feedback to the South SGP by Monday 
th
27 June 2010. Copies of the detailed marked-up comments are available on request.  
3 Background ��� South Gloucestershire���s Sustainable Community Strategy. 
The strategy presents a clear vision for the future of South Gloucestershire to 2026. The 
current version is an update of the February 2008 version and a further update is planned in 
three years time. The South Gloucestershire Partnership (SGP) has led the development of the 
vision and priorities in the Sustainable Community Strategy and will monitor their 
implementation, reporting progress.  The SGP also oversees the three yearly review and 
update of the Sustainable Community Strategy.  
 
The programme for producing the Sustainable Community Strategy is given in Appendix 1. 
 
4 Discussion of issues ��� Health Aspects of the Sustainable Community Strategy 
 
The strategy identifies seven priority themes each with its own set of specific objectives. The 
objectives are aspirational and will depend on more detailed action plans for their delivery.  The 
priority themes are wide-ranging and cover the full spectrum of SGP activity, as follows: 
 
1. Investing in children and young people  
2. Being healthier  
3. Modernising health and community care services  
4. Managing future development  
5. Promoting safer and stronger communities  
6. Valuing the environment  
7. Maintaining economic prosperity  
If you need this document in a different format, please telephone Lucy Jones on 0117 3302 468 
 
G:\Communications Team\Website updates\17 June\Item 6.2 Community Strategyv2.doc Board Paper Page 1 of 6 South Gloucestershire Primary Care Trust: Briefing on Sustainable Community Strategy 
 
 
Transport is included as part of priority theme (4) ���managing future development��� and is recognised 
as a cross-cutting theme relevant to all the priority themes. 
 
Almost all of the priority themes are affected by a predicted growth in the South Gloucestershire 
population. The review has identified that growth predictions are not consistently reflected 
throughout the strategy. In one part of the text, it is stated that the growth proposed by the draft 
Regional Spatial Strategy (RSS) is not sustainable or deliverable but it is not clear what other 
growth predictions are being applied elsewhere in the text. The review will seek clarification on this 
point. 
 
Health aspects are represented directly by priority themes (2) and (3). The specific priorities within 
these themes were drafted by the Directors of Public Health, Primary Care and Adult & Social 
Care. The commitments reflect the strategic plans and priorities of the PCT under the following 
headings: 
 
��� Being healthier  
o Healthy lifestyles 
o Inequalities in health 
o Threats to health 
 
��� Modernising health and community care services  
o Quality of life 
o Positive contribution 
o Exercising choice and control 
o Freedom from discrimination and harassment 
o Economic well-being 
o Personal dignity and respect 
o Modernisation 
 
There are no significant outstanding comments on ���modernising health and community care 
services���. The priorities under ���being healthier��� clearly reflect the intent of the Public Health 
Directorate but two additional points are proposed to strengthen and clarify the proposals. The 
first is to mention certain key healthy lifestyle behaviours explicitly (i.e. tobacco control, 
sensible drinking, healthy eating, being physically active, etc.).  The second is to emphasise 
the importance of partnership working (in line with the draft Health Improvement Strategy) in 
preventing ill-health and reducing demand on services by maximizing the benefit gained from 
collective resources. 
 
All of the other priority themes (1, 4, 5, 6 and 7) have some bearing on health. 
 
Priority theme (1) ���investing in children and young people��� represents health aspects well 
following the inclusion of previous comments. Only minor comments are outstanding. 
 
The review of priority theme (4) ���managing future development��� finds that health aspects could 
be represented more strongly and in particular a commitment should be made to exploit the 
pivotal role planning and design play a in tackling sedentary lifestyles, obesity and health 
inequality (e.g. through enabling active travel). In addition, new housing development and 
regeneration provide opportunities to ���build in��� health from the start and to improve existing 
environments. 
 
The review of priority theme (5) ���safer and stronger communities��� finds that health aspects are 
generally well represented and in particular the commitments to increase employment and 
reduce derivation in Priority Neighbourhoods are welcomed as these will address the 
determinants of health and help reduce health inequalities. Only minor comments are 
outstanding. 
G:\Communications Team\Website updates\17 June\Item 6.2 Community Strategyv2.doc  
 Board Paper Page 2 of 6 South Gloucestershire Primary Care Trust: Briefing on Sustainable Community Strategy 
 
 
The review of priority theme (6) ���valuing the environment��� finds that the specific objectives 
would have inherent health benefits. Only minor comments are outstanding. 
 
Priority theme (7) ���maintaining economic prosperity��� is relevant as it improves wider 
determinants of health. This driver could be mentioned as part of ���setting the scene���. There are 
no outstanding comments on the specific objectives. 
 
5 Financial implications  
No financial implications for NHS South Gloucestershire relate to this paper. 
6 Implementation and Review of Progress 
 
The programme for producing the Sustainable Community Strategy is given in Appendix 1. 
 
7 Legal implications 
There are no legal implications for NHS South Gloucestershire in relation to the SCS. 
 
8 Risk Implications 
The risk of negative health implications arising from the SCS (and the risk of missing 
opportunities to improve health) should be reduced by NHS South Gloucestershire engaging in 
the consultation process. 
 
9 Implications for health inequalities 
The review has sought to ensure that health inequalities are appropriately addressed in the 
SCS. 
 
10 Implications for equalities  (Black and Other Minority Ethnic/Disability/Age Issues) 
As part of the SCS process, an Equalities Impact Assessment will be completed. 
 
11 Consultation and Communication including Public Involvement 
The first consultation draft South Gloucestershire���s Sustainable Community Strategy has 
recently been published for key stakeholder consultation.  Stakeholder comments are to be 
incorporated and a second draft published for public consultation by mid July 2010. 
 
12 Links to: 
 
 Tick as Element Explanation / Comment 
applicable 
Strategic Objectives ���   
Standards for Better    
Health 
WCC Competency     
Use of Resources    
 
13 Conclusions 
 
G:\Communications Team\Website updates\17 June\Item 6.2 Community Strategyv2.doc  
 Board Paper Page 3 of 6 South Gloucestershire Primary Care Trust: Briefing on Sustainable Community Strategy 
 
In conclusion, the Consultation Draft of the SCS already includes most of the relevant 
health aspects. A limited number of insertions are proposed by this review to strengthen 
th
and maximize the health opportunities. These will be fed back to the SGP by Monday 27 
June 2010 for inclusion in the consultation process together with more minor comments.  
 
 
 
 
Prepared by: 
 
Natalie Field, Deputy Director of Public Health 
 
Presented by Dr Chris Payne, Director of Public Health 
  
10 June 2010 
G:\Communications Team\Website updates\17 June\Item 6.2 Community Strategyv2.doc  
 Board Paper Page 4 of 6 South Gloucestershire Primary Care Trust: Briefing on Sustainable Community Strategy

							Digestive disorders


 
	
		

	
		Service nameTherapy services

Description


 Therapists can help anyone, from babies to elderly people and from those with passing problems, such as broken limbs or strains, to those with chronic diseases who may need to manage pain and disability for the rest of their lives.

Genetic or acquired diseases mean that for some people there is no choice - they will need the help of therapists. For many of these patients there is no cure: it is more a matter of managing pain and disability so that they can lead as full and healthy a life
But, for most people, problems that therapists treat can be avoided by leading a healthy lifestyle and being sensible about how you use your body.

If you are a therapist who would like to work for the Kent and Medway NHS, please go to our job opportunities pages. Website links related to therapy, with sites mainly catering for professionals, are available on the therapists page in the For Professionals section.

Four errors.... and a conspiracy? The effectiveness of schools in Wales
	Publication Date: 01-12-1998


														Visit this website
													

This paper addresses the issue of using raw-score indicators to compare the performance of groups of educational establishments.

Despite the growth of sophisticated, some might say over-sophisticated, ways of estimating the value-added to a performance by an institution such as a school, raw-score comparisons continue to be made by researchers, journalists and, most frighteningly, by policy-makers. In Wales, whole programmes of improvement measures and targets have been predicated upon the unproved notion that schools in Wales are under-performing, that students are 'schooled to fail', that the majority of secondary schools in Wales--English-medium comprehensives--should be looking to English schools and Welsh-medium schools for their models of improvement strategies. Similar forms of comparison have more recently been used to suggest that the compulsory learning of Welsh hinders the learning of other modern languages. The substantive purpose of this paper is to argue that all such comparisons are rhetorically misleading, and to show that under closer analysis the differences and effect-sizes claimed by the advocates of these positions are statistically insignificant. The lack of difference is so easily discernible in the light of background factors, that one wonders why politicians, some academics and the media continue to cite the differential effectiveness of schools in Wales in support of their preferred programmes of action.

Oxford Review of Education, Vol. 24, No. 4 (Dec., 1998), pp. 459-472

	AuthorsGorard, S.
	PublisherRoutledge, part of the Taylor & Francis Group
	TypeJournal article

Tel: +44 (0)2920 471 520 Email: wales@heacademy.ac.uk

							Sports injury


 
	
		

	
		Service namePhysiotherapy

Description


Physiotherapists help and treat people of all ages with physical problems caused by illness, accident or ageing. 
This service provides a musculo-skeletal out-patients clinic, care of the elderly, rehabilitation after surgery or injury, hand therapy plus help for those with breathing, neurological or rheumatological (such as muscle, tendon, joint, bone, or nerve) problems which cause discomfort and disability

It can help adult and paediatric patients with disabilities, injuries or diseases by providing rehabilitation following surgery, trauma, injury, disease or disability.





Open times


8am - 3pm Monday - Friday. 





Address


West View Hospital 
Plummer Lane 
Kent 
Tenterden 
TN30 6TX





Waiting times


Not currently available

            Course Name:
        
    

    
			
        The full name of the course
    
		

    
    



                    	
                        Diploma In Relationship Therapy with Gender and Sexual Diversities
                    
	
                        



    
        
            Course Category:
        
    

    
			
        Courses are grouped into categories or types to help you find the type of course you need.
    
		

    
    



                    	
                        One year programme
                    
	
                        



    
        
            Course Provider:
        
    

    
			
        The organisation which provides (and delivers) the course
    
		

    
    



                    	
                        Pink Therapy
                    
	
                        



    
        
            Trainers:
        
    

    
			
        
    
		

    
    



                    	
                        	
                                
                                    
                                        
                                    

                                    Leah Davidson

            Cost Notes:
        
    

    
				
        
    
			

    
    



                    	
                        ?2,500 plus up to ?800  depending on which Alternative Sexualities Modules are required.
                    
	
                        



    
        
            Discount:
        
    

    
				
        
    
			

    
    



                    	
                        
                    
	
                        



    
        
            Qualification:
        
    

    
				
        
    
			

    
    



                    	
                        We are looking at getting this course externally validated
                    
	
                        This information is provisional and subject to revision.

This course runs over one year and offers an in-depth training in understanding and working therapeutically with a diverse range of relationships, e.g., monogamous, open, poly and kink relationships. 

?The course will also address differences between gender and sexual diversities and the implications of working at the dynamic interface of these relationships. Intersectionality will provide a particular frame of reference in considering relationships throughout the course.

 

?This training will have particular appeal for qualified therapists who are wishing to develop their practice skills in working with couples and other relationship configurations. Ideally, applicants will have ongoing opportunities for working with clients in relationships, and will draw on this learning throughout the course.

 

?The course will provide an understanding and application of an integrative model of therapy, drawing on systemic, psychoanalytic and transpersonal approaches. Opportunities will exist for consideration of psychosexual therapy and particular sexual practices relating to gender and sexual diversities will also be examined

Dates:

Sat 14 Sept ?	Introduction to Psychosexual Therapy with Gender and Sexual Diversities day 1*

 

Sun 15 Sept 	Introduction to Psychosexual Therapy with Gender and Sexual Diversities day 2*

 

Sat 28 Sept 	Bisexuality In The Therapy Room*

 

Sun 29 Sept 	Understanding Polyamory and Non-Monogamies*

 

Sat 5 Oct 		Dip Relationship Therapy day 1

 

Sun 6 Oct 		Dip Relationship Therapy day?2

 

Sat 19 Oct 	Understanding Kink and BDSM*

 

Sun 20 Oct 	Without Condoms*

 

Sat 2 Nov 		Dip Relationship Therapy day?3

 

Sat 16 Nov 	I'm Too Sexy: Understanding Sexual Compulsivity in Gay and Bisexual Men*

 

Sun 17 Nov 	Asexualities: Intimacy and Desire*

 

Sat 7 Dec 		Dip Relationship Therapy day?4

 

Sat 11 Jan 	Dip Relationship Therapy day?5

 

Sun 12 Jan 	Dip Relationship Therapy day?6

 

Sat 8 Feb 		Dip Relationship Therapy day?7

 

Sat 8 March 	Dip Relationship Therapy day 8

 

Sat 5 April 	Dip Relationship Therapy day?9

 

Sat 10 May 	Dip Relationship Therapy day 10

 

Fri 6 June 		Dip Relationship Therapy day 11? Presentations

 

Sat 7 June 	Dip Relationship Therapy day 12- Presentations

 

Sun 8 June 	Dip Relationship Therapy ?1/2 day (10-2pm) Closing and Evaluation

?

Saturdays teaching date will start at 1pm to 7pm.

Sundays will start at 10am to 5pm.

Friday will start at 3pm to 9pm.

Registration on all dates will start 30 min before.

?

Dates marked with an asterisk constitute our Certificate in Alternative Sexualities. These are Core Modules for the Diploma training and we recognise that some students will have taken some of these Modules previously and won't need to repeat them.

Fees

?2,500 plus up to ?800? depending on which Alternative Sexualities Modules are required.

How to join:

Admission to the Diploma is by interview. Please download an application form from this link

?

 

Course Facilitators:

 

The course will be run by two qualified and experienced Associates of Pink Therapy:

 

?

 

Leah Davidson is a qualified individual and relationship therapist who has worked in private practice and in the NHS for 25 years. She trained in Relationship Therapy at ?Revision Centre for Integrative Psychosynthesis and works extensively with different forms of relationship and with a range or gender and sexual diversity clients, while contributing to trainings in this area. She is an Advanced Accredited Sexual Diversity therapist, a Clinical Associate of Pink Therapy, and is currently tutor on the Post Graduate Diploma in Gender and Sexual Diversity Therapy.

 

?

 

Dr Damian Mc Cann is a qualified Systemic Psychotherapist and holds a Consultant Family & Systemic Psychotherapy Post within the NHS. He is also employed by the Tavistock Centre for Couple Relationships where he is completing his Psychoanalytic Couple Psychotherapy Training. He recently completed his Doctorate in Systemic Psychotherapy researching the meaning of violence and abuse within the couple relationships of gay men. He has extensive experience in working therapeutically with gender and sexual diversities and has contributed to a range of trainings in this area.?

						Nid yw Golwg360 yn gyfrifol am y sylwadau isod nac o angenrheidrwydd yn cytuno â nhw.


						Gofynnwn yn garedig i ddarllenwyr wneud defnydd doeth o’r gwasanaeth sylwadau – ni ddylid ymosod ar unigolion na chynnwys unrhyw sylwadau a all fod yn enllibus. Meddyliwch cyn teipio os gwelwch yn dda.


						Er mwyn cael trafodaeth dda, gofynnwn i chi ddefnyddio eich enw go iawn a pheidio â chuddio y tu ôl i ffugenwau.


						Gofynwn yn garedig i bawb ddarllen canllawiau ‘Cyfrannu i elfennau rhyngweithiol Golwg360’ yn ofalus cyn gadael sylwadau ar y gwasanaeth.


						Nodi Camddefnydd
Os ydych chi’n credu bod y neges yma’n torri rheolau’r wefan, cliciwch ar y ddolen ’Nodi camddefnydd’ sy’n ymddangos wrth ymyl pob sylwad. Os bydd dau berson yn anhapus, bydd y neges yn dod yn ôl at Golwg360 i’w ddilysu.

	 Choose Well 

	Friday 16th Nov 2012  by LINkAdmin 

	
	
	
		
		
		
	

	
	
		If you become unwell or are injured make sure you choose the right NHS service to make sure you get the best treatment.


This high profile awareness campaign is designed to help people get the best possible treatment by selecting the service that is right for them. By choosing well, people can help to reduce the burden on essential emergency services.


The pdf on the right is a generic poster indicating which services are best for when people feel unwell.

title: Wales: educational attainment at age 16 - The Poverty Site
text:
Wales: educational attainment at age 16 - The Poverty Site













 


	Home
	 Indicators
	Reports
	Key facts
	UK summary
	What's new
	Search
	   About
	Contact us







 Search







  
  
  
  














     


	Wales

			Educational attainment at age 16
	
			

			
		





Graphs on this page:

	          Over time
	          By deprivation
	          By LA



Supporting information:

	          Definitions and data sources









Key points

        
	15% of 16-year-olds in 1999/00 did not obtain 5 or more GCSEs at any 
	grade or vocational equivalent ('Level 1').  By 2009/10, 
  this proportion had fallen to 10%.
	51% of 16-year-olds in 1999/00 did not obtain the higher threshold of 5 
	or more GCSEs at grade C or above or vocational equivalent ('Level 2').  By 2009/10, 
  this proportion had fallen to 36%.
	The rate of reduction is - at around a third - similar for both 
	thresholds.  Note, however, that at least part of these reductions 
	since 2005/06 has been due to a widening of what is included as a 
	'vocational equivalent'.
	Because of precise issues of definition (what is included in 
	'equivalents', what pupils are included, what schools are included, etc), it is not at all clear that 
	the results in Wales are completely comparable to those in England (which is 
	why there is no graph with such a comparison).  
	Comparison with the equivalent 
	indicator for England does, however, suggest that:	For both thresholds, the rate of reduction in Wales has 
	actually been somewhat slower than its English equivalent.

	
	The proportion in Wales not obtaining the higher threshold was similar to 
	its equivalent in England a decade ago but is now noticeably 
	higher.

	The proportion in Wales not obtaining the lower threshold has been 
	higher than its equivalent in England throughout the last decade and, 
	indeed, is higher than that in any of the English regions.



	
	The proportion of pupils failing to obtain at least 5 GCSEs at any grade 
	or vocational equivalent ('Level 1') has been falling at a similar rate in all groups of schools, whatever their number of pupils from 
  disadvantaged backgrounds.  In absolute 
	terms, however, the fall has been greatest for those schools with high 
	numbers of pupils from disadvantaged backgrounds.  So, for example, among the tenth of schools with the highest proportion 
  entitled to free school meals, the proportion of pupils failing to get 5 GCSEs 
  fell from 28% in 1999/00 to 19% in 2008/09, a fall of 9 percentage points.  
	What all this means is that, whilst there is still substantial gap between performance in schools with many pupils 
  from disadvantaged backgrounds and performance in other schools, this gap is 
	less than it was a decade ago.
	Twice as many pupils in Blaenau Gwent do not obtain 5 or more GCSEs or 
	vocational equivalent as in some other authorities.


top


Graph 1: Over time


View Graph as PDF (resizeable)   Right click to save large version of Graph as PNG
top


Graph 2: By deprivation


View Graph as PDF (resizeable)   Right click to save large version of Graph as PNG
top


Graph 3: By local authority


View Graph as PDF (resizeable)   Right click to save large version of Graph as PNG
top


Definitions and data sources


The first graph shows the proportion of students (defined as 
pupils aged 15 at 31 August in the calendar year prior to sitting the exams) 
not obtaining five or more GCSEs (or vocational equivalent) at grade C or above 
(termed the 'Level 2' threshold by the Welsh Assembly Government).  The data is split 
between those who obtained less than 
five GCSEs (termed the 'Level 1' threshold by the Welsh Assembly Government) and those who obtained 5 or more GCSEs but less than 5 at grade C or above. 

The data source for the first graph is the 
Welsh Assembly Government's publication entitled 
Examination results in Wales and 
its predecessors.  The data covers all schools 
in Wales.  The lower threshold - Level 1 - is understood to be effectively 
the same as 'fewer than 5 GCSEs of any grade (or equivalent)'.  The higher 
threshold - Level 2 - is understood to be effectively the same as '5 or more GCSEs (or equivalent) but less than 5 at grade C or above'.  
Up to 2005/06, the only 'vocational equivalents' included were GNVQs and NVQs 
but, from 2006/07, all qualifications approved for pre-16 and 16-18 use in Wales 
are included.  This widening of definition has meant the inclusion of a 
larger range of qualifications and thus a lowering in the proportions not 
achieving the particular thresholds.  Note that the proportion with no qualifications is not 
shown as this data is no longer published.

The second graph compares the proportion of students 
failing to obtain the Level 1 threshold for groups of schools with differing
proportions of pupils receiving free school 
meals.  For each year's data, both the results and the proportion receiving 
free school meals relate to that year.  The grouping of the schools has 
been chosen to best illustrate the differing trends.

The data source for the second graph is school-level data 
from the National Assembly for Wales (the data is not publicly available).  It 
covers all local authority maintained secondary schools.  Where either GCSE 
results or free school meal data for particular schools for particular years is 
not known, these schools have been excluded from the analysis for that year.

The third graph shows the 
proportion of students who fail to obtain the Level 1 threshold - five or more 
GCSEs or equivalent - by local education 
authority.  To improve its statistical reliability, the data is the average 
for the latest three years.

As with the first graph, the data source for the third graph is the 
Welsh Assembly Government's publication entitled 
Examination results in Wales 
and its predecessors.

Note that none of the graphs provide a comparison between Wales and the 
English regions.  This is because, with Wales now publishing only their results 
against Level 1 and 2 thresholds, it is not at all clear that the data is directly 
comparable.

Overall adequacy of the indicator: medium.  While the data 
itself is sound enough, the choice of the particular levels of exam success is a 
matter of judgement.
