		Black Country History is a searchable website which allows users to find information about documents, maps, photographs, art works, objects and more held by archives and museums services within the Black Country.


The eight partners involved in this website are:

Children Gathering Seaweed OP47 1800 - 1837

			Oil painting showing a young girl and boy collecting seaweed into a basket. There are steep cliffs behind them and a small building.

			Wolverhampton Arts and Museums Service

			
Kinver 1979/12a

			Oil painting by Edwin Grice showing Kinver Edge and the Kinver rock houses with figures walking in the foreground

			Dudley Museums Service

			
Boats and Beach 1976/57

			Oil painting by Sir Alfred East showing boats pulled up onto a beach. Figures walk along the beach and a small group pull a boat out from the sea. Fishing equipment is in the foreground.

			Dudley Museums Service

			
Pass of Aberglaslyn 1974/16

			Oil painting by B W Leader showing alandscape at the Pass of Aberglaslyn. A river runs through large boulders deposited on the river bed. A mountain can be seen to the right and a pine forest to the left.

			Dudley Museums Service

			
The Head of Loch Lomond 1974/15

			Oil painting by B W Leaser showing a stream cascading down a hillside at Loch Lomond

			Dudley Museums Service

			
Cliffs and Sea 1971/43

			Oil painting by Roland Hipkins showing a seascape with white chalk cliffs on the right and the open sea on the left.

			Dudley Museums Service

			
Dudley Castle 1887 1951/1

			Oil painting by Sidney Herbert showing a view of Dudley Castle on Catle Hill. A group of figures are near the ruins.

			Dudley Museums Service

			
The Windmill, Las Palmas 1944/3

			Oil painting by Sir Frank Brangwyn showing a windmill on top of a cliff, with another turreted building beyond it. Figures walk along the base of the cliff.

			Dudley Museums Service

			
The Elbe from the Bastie, Saxony 1938/4

			Oil painting by Reco Capey showing a steam boat sailing down the Elbe River, Saxony. A castle is on the hillside to the bottom right. Rolling green hills surround the river and go into the distance.

			Dudley Museums Service

			
Landscape 1937/104

			Oil Painting by Albert Goodwin of a landscape. There is a river in the forground, pasture with sheep grazing and a cliff in the background

			Dudley Museums Service

			
St. Malo 1952/1

			Oil painting by C C W Nevinson showing a view looking from a vantage point across the beach and bay at St. Malo. Boats can be seen out to sea and a building on a small island just off the shore.

			Dudley Museums Service

			
Namur OP733 1878

			Oil painting showing a coastal scene with boats on the water. Grand buildings can be seen on a hill top in the centre of the painting and there are two bridges spanning the water at either side. People can be seen in the boats.

			Wolverhampton Arts and Museums Service

			
Light House at Llanddwyn OP567 1865 - 1918

			Oil painting of a coastal scene with a lighthouse set on a cliff.

			Wolverhampton Arts and Museums Service

			
Coast Scene OP478 1860 - 1895

			Oil painting of a figure sat in a rowing boat on the white stony shore. Framing the boat, sand and sea are grey cliffs. In the distance the light catches the green on top of the cliffs and the white of the cliff edge.

			Wolverhampton Arts and Museums Service

			
	1
	2

We support this continued broad power to make provision for social care services and we welcome the proposed definition of social services. ?As discussed in the forward to the draft Bill any changes must make access to services easier and give service users a strong voice and real control of the social care process. ?We welcome the proposal to add social work within the 'social care servies' definition.

	ReachOutRCA Drawing Workshop With Teachers and Pupils From Erith School






                    
                

                
                

                
                    	School Teachers
Working Together

	Our programme is intended to be a learning process for everyone; we hope that you will find the creative exchanges with workshops leaders and the opportunity to work with your pupils beyond the curriculum to be inspiring. 

The workshops are an introduction to an artist, designer or maker and their practice, to new ways of working and looking, and to the possibilities of a life in art or design. Workshops are not directed by the school curriculum however you will find many ways to link the content and ideas with learning objectives.

We aim to work particularly with pupils who express a particular creative interest or aptitude. We invite them to take responsibility for their future direction by negotiating challenges and being active participants in the success of their workshop. We hope that workshops will develop confidence and critical thinking by encouraging a questioning and playful response, and offer an opportunity for pupils to find a voice that may not have been apparent before.

ReachOutRCA offers an invaluable opportunity for teachers to work alongside those at the forefront of contemporary art and design practice, giving them observation and participation time outside the demands of a curriculum-led day. By working with teachers as well as pupils we aim to contribute to increasing diversity in higher education and widen the reach of our programme. 

Please contact us at reachout@rca.ac.uk to discuss opportunities for working together.

                Letter 

            


            
                
                to
                
            


            

        

        
            



Summary

 CD informs AS of the position of the Council of the Geological Society on recommending J. B. Jukes for a geological survey of Newfoundland. Feels Jukes?s application would have best chance of success if Sedgwick, his Professor at Cambridge, wrote a letter. 




Transcription


?

?

My dear Sedgwick

I talked to several members of the Council on Wednesday, about Mr Jukes? appointment, & all seemed to think it would be a very good thing if he has the zeal & courage to go.? You probably may not be aware that he addressed a letter to me (as Secret. of the Soc.), applying to the Council to recommend him to the Governor of Newfoundland.? After deliberation, the Council agreed that it could not, as a body, take such a recommendation on itself, & accordingly I was directed to write to Mr Jukes to this effect, & at the same time to express the wish of the Council, that his application might be successful.? At the suggestion of some present, I told him the best recommendation he could send to the Governor, would be from you, (if you were so disposed), as being the Professor at Cambridge.? And it was in consequence of this, I presume, that Mr Jukes wrote to you.? If he intends going I shall be most happy to assist him, with any suggestions or advice which might occur to me, or in any other way.? Mr Whewell, moreover, said he should be ready, to give him a recommendation to the Governor, as he was acquainted with Mr Jukes, when at Cambridge.? Mr Greenough said his knowledge of him, was too slight for this, but nevertheless he seemed to think him a very proper person.? I shall be happy to do anything, you may wish to further such an undertaking, and I feel the more bound to do so, as I in similar circumstances, received much assistance, from Many.?

Believe me | Most truly yours? | Chas. Darwin 
 36?Grt. Marlbro? Str

Friday 21st.?

	News

        	Health check for Buckinghamshire PCT

	Buckinghamshire Primary Care Trust (PCT) has been awarded a ?fair?  rating for its Quality of Servicesand ?weak? for Use of  Resourcesin the Healthcare Commission Annual Health Check, announced  today (Thursday October 18). This Annual Health Check looks at how the trust  performed in the 2006/2007 financial year, and is the second year in which these  ratings have been used to measure the overall performance of PCTs nationally.

The Health Check looks at the performance of a trust in two main  areas:

 

Quality of Services: This covers the range of services  and the way a trust is run. It also covers how well it met a range of core  standards and how well it meets existing and new targets.

 

Use of  Resources:This looks at how well a trust manages and plans its  finances, how it monitors the money spent and how it makes sure it offers good  value for money through its services.

The views of the local  community including Buckinghamshire County Council Overview & Scrutiny  Committee and the PCTs Public and Patient Involvement Forum are also included in  the overall rating assessment.

The PCT was awarded a ?weak? rating  for the Use of Resources by the Healthcare Commission, partly as a result of an  end of year deficit in March 2007. Whilst this rating is a disappointing one for  the PCT, since the information for the Annual

Health Check was  gathered in March 2007 the PCT has made significant progress

in addressing  these historical financial issues and has put plans in place to achieve  sustained financial stability.

It?s strategy ?Preparing  Buckinghamshire PCT for the Future? (available at www.buckpct.nhs.uk ) outlines  five key objectives for improving the health and well being of the local  population, including managing the PCT?s healthcare contracts effectively and  delivering high quality yet cost effective prescribing services to ensure  optimal value for money.

Financial and risk management processes have  been reviewed and improved to achieve a healthier financial position by the end  of 2007/2008. However, because of the way in which the Use of Resources rating  is calculated, it is likely that these actions will not fully be reflected in  the Use of Resources score until 2008/2009.

 

In addition,  Quality of Services was rated as ?fair? because the PCT did not meet a  sufficient number of its national targets, particularly in reducing adult  smoking rates (69% of trusts failed to meet this target) and improving outcomes  for patients with long term conditions, for example by providing community  matrons (77% of trusts failed to meet this target). This rating again  reflects the position as ofthe end of March 2007, a period of  considerable organisational change. The PCT has made substantial progress in  improving its performance since then, notably in reducing cancer wait times and  increasing access to primary care.

The PCT performed particularly  well in the following areas:

	Supporting people with substance misuse problems
	Reducing mortality rates in breast cancer and heart disease
	Review of diabetes patients in primary care


Also included in the overall assessment this year were reviews of the  PCT?s Public Health services, and services for patients with diabetes. The PTC  received a ?fair? rating for both  reviews.

 

In addition  all safety standards were met by May 2007 and by July 2007 the PCT had met all  the remaining quality standards, highlighting the high standards of safety and  quality we have now achieved.

The PCT is working in partnership  with other health providers, notably Buckinghamshire Hospitals NHS Trust, South  Central Ambulance Trust (formerly Two Shires Ambulance Trust) and the  Oxfordshire & Buckinghamshire Mental Health Partnership NHS Trust to ensure  a shared understanding of the challenges we face and an agreement on priority  areas for joint action.

 

Janet Fitzgerald, Chief Executive for  Buckinghamshire PCT said: ??2006/2007 was a difficult year for the PCT and the  pressures on our Trust show no signs of easing.? Although we are pleased to have  been awarded a ?fair? rating for the quality of our services, we recognise that  there is still much work to do. ?There have been notable successes within some  of the standards we did achieve, and since the assessment was carried out we  have made considerable advances in many areas. For example, the PCT is on track  to meet or exceed its targets for reducing the number of cases of  healthcare-acquired infections like MRSA and Clostridium ?Difficile. We are  confident that the PCT can build on these and other successes to improve its  quality rating still further next year. We are aiming to achieve an improved Use  of Resources rating by 2008/2009?.

?While these ratings give a  more rounded picture than the previous star ratings did they cannot reflect the  incredibly hard work staff have put in to meet patient expectations and new  standards. We will be looking at the areas where we have

not performed as  well as we could. The challenge for us all in the next two years will be to do  better still, and continue the improvement journey that the PCT has already  begun?.

?We will continue to work to deliver quality services and the  Trust and its staff are committed to treating the people of Buckinghamshire well  and providing the best possible healthcare?.

For more information contact:

Richard Burton

Communications Manager

01494 552 256

Home > Listening to you > Consultations > Improving trauma care across the West Midlands			

							
					Improving trauma care across the West Midlands

					

					The NHS in the West Midlands is proposing to transform the care people receive when they suffer major trauma by introducing an improved system of care across the region.

Major trauma is defined as serious injuries which may be life threatening. The creation of new trauma care networks will help patients by increasing survival rates, shortening recovery times and reducing disability from injury. This is because major trauma centres have the specialist staff, equipment and technology on one site to treat these serious and/or life threatening injuries.

By developing a region-wide trauma care system we can ensure that everyone in the West Midlands has access to the same high quality trauma care services.

The West Midlands Strategic Commissioning Group agreed that establishing 3 major trauma centres plus the Birmingham Children?s Hospital as the major trauma centre for children, is the preferred option.

More details about this can be found in the accompanying??Engagement Briefing.

We would value your views about the proposal to establish a West Midlands trauma care system. Please read the Engagement Briefing which explains more about this and then complete the questionnaire online at??http://www.surveymonkey.com/s/majortrauma or you can send us your views by email to??info@legacy.benpct.nhs.uk.

Your feedback will be greatly appreciated. Please note that we need your views by 20th December 2011.
